sets.name: Drought Wallbreaker
sets.description: Thanks to its superb coverage and high Special Attack stat, Mega Charizard Y is a terrifying wallbreaker. Drought + Solar Beam allows Mega Charizard Y to subdue Water-types such Rotom-W, Gastrodon, and Tapu Fini, further restricting its defensive counterplay. Fire Blast is preferred to hit as hard as possible, though Flamethrower's perfect accuracy and greater PP make it worth consideration. Weather Ball is an interesting option, as it presents a challenge to rain teams by dealing considerable damage to Pelipper on the switch, but it comes at the cost of Mega Charizard Y losing its primary STAB move outside of sun. Scorching Sands pressures Heatran, Toxapex, and Skeledirge, while Focus Blast threatens Mega Tyranitar. Mega Charizard Y's tremendous wallbreaking prowess allows late-game sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult, Dragonite, and Volcarona to take advantage of Unaware walls that have been compromised, such as Skeledirge and Clodsire. Mega Charizard Y's sun support benefits Protosynthesis users such as Great Tusk. Mega Charizard Y appreciates entry hazard control from teammates such as Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Kartana, as it is extremely susceptible to Stealth Rock. It also struggles to break bulky Dragon-types such as Dragonite and Mega Latias as well as special walls like Clodsire and Hippowdon. Weavile, Tyranitar, and Kingambit subsequently form strong offensive cores with Mega Charizard Y, as they are able to Pursuit trap its aforementioned checks, with the former being able to deal with Hippowdon as well. Mega Charizard Y's middling Speed tier and unremarkable physical bulk leave it prone to being revenge killed by faster threats such as Dragapult, Mega Lopunny, and Tapu Koko. Therefore, bulky switch-ins such as Assault Vest Tangrowth, Ting-Lu, and Landorus-T make for good teammates.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Mega Charizard X is a powerful setup sweeper and wallbreaker thanks to the sheer power of its Tough Claws-boosted Flare Blitz. Earthquake covers a vast majority of Fire-resistant Pokemon, including Heatran, Toxapex, Garganacl, and Skeledirge, as well as Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Kingambit without the recoil. Aside from granting Mega Charizard X more setup opportunities, Roost compensates for Flare Blitz recoil and its Stealth Rock weakness, allowing it to take advantage of its typing and natural bulk to soft check common foes like Volcarona, Mega Scizor, and Choice Scarf Kartana as well as preventing revenge killing attempts from Mega Lopunny and Kingambit. Dragon Claw is an alternative on hyper offense teams where the longevity isn't as necessary, which allows Mega Charizard X to hit Dragonite, Mega Latias, and Garchomp as well as providing neutral coverage against foes like Rotom-W, Tera Water Skeledirge, and Tera Grass Heatran. Offensive partners like Kartana, Weavile, Iron Valiant, and Kingambit can pressure the opposition early-game for Mega Charizard X to sweep more easily, as they can cripple and either pressure or overwhelm shared checks in Toxapex, Slowbro, Skeledirge, and Iron Defense Garganacl; in return, it threatens Tangrowth for Kartana, handles Gholdengo for Iron Valiant, and melts other Steel-types like Mega Scizor and Corviknight for them. Pivots like Dragapult, Rotom-W, and Tornadus-T bring Mega Charizard X in safely via U-turn on Pokemon like Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Gholdengo, respectively; the latter two in particular can remove entry hazards with Defog so it can enter the field unscathed, especially if it's not running Roost and hasn't Mega Evolved yet. Dual screen setters found on hyper offense teams, such as Tapu Koko and Grimmsnarl, give Mega Charizard X an easier time setting up.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description: Clefable's great movepool, passable bulk, and Magic Guard + Soft-Boiled give it a unique niche as a defensive Fairy-type. It's able to fulfill many roles such as a Stealth Rock setter, a support Pokemon thanks to Thunder Wave and Knock Off crippling its checks like Heatran and Mega Scizor, and a potent sweeper with Calm Mind. Magic Guard lets Clefable absorb status moves like Toxic and Will-O-Wisp for teammates like Ting-Lu, Ferrothorn, and Gastrodon. It also allows it to ignore entry hazards, helping it check Pokemon like Mega Lopunny and Dragapult. Rocky Helmet punishes U-turn from Mega Lopunny and Landorus-T. The given EV spread allows it to survive two Returns from Mega Lopunny with Leftovers recovery while also checking special attackers like Choice Specs Dragapult. If Rocky Helmet is used, an alternative spread of 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with a Bold nature is recommended. Tera Water allows Clefable to have a better matchup into rain teams while resisting Steel-type attacks from Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Kingambit, allowing Clefable to catch them off-guard and cripple them. Tera Steel, on the other hand, allows Clefable to catch Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant with a Thunder Wave. Entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Ferrothorn appreciate Clefable's ability to incapacitate common Defog users such as Tornadus-T and Rotom-W thanks to Knock Off. They also appreciate having one moveslot being freed if Clefable carries Stealth Rock. Similarly, Clefable can cripple common entry hazard setters like Ferrothorn and Heatran, helping Defog users like the aforementioned Tornadus-T and Rotom-W perform their role. Toxapex works well with Clefable, as it checks Poison- and Steel-types like Iron Moth and Mega Scizor, helping Clefable spread Thunder Wave or set up with Calm Mind. They can also both overwhelm Ferrothorn, as the former can burn it and the latter nullifies Leech Seed's recovery. If Thunder Wave is used, Hex users like Gholdengo and Dragapult can be used to break Pokemon like Toxapex and Heatran that would otherwise stop Clefable from sweeping with Calm Mind.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Slowbro's valuable defensive typing, solid physical bulk, and remarkable longevity between Slack Off + Regenerator make it a very reliable defensive pivot, capable of consistently checking dangerous physical attackers like Urshifu-R, Mega Medicham, Mega Lopunny, and Mega Swampert. The combination of Teleport + Future Sight lets Slowbro support its offensive teammates by providing them free entry while forcing immense pressure on a prospective switch-in. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Slowbro to switch freely in spite of any entry hazards. Tera Steel can be used in a pinch to check foes like Kingambit, Mega Tyranitar, and Tapu Lele, letting it either cripple them with a Scald burn or use Teleport into a revenge killer. Wallbreakers such as Kingambit, Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta appreciate Slowbro's FuturePort to bring them in safely on foes like Ferrothorn and Garganacl and subsequently pressure their switch-ins like Great Tusk, Clodsire, and Toxapex with the impending Future Sight. Specially defensive Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Heatran help cover threats like Tapu Koko, Volcarona, and Gholdengo, respectively; in return, Slowbro deals with Ground- and Fighting-types like Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Urshifu-R. Corviknight, Tornadus-T, and Buzzwole cover other physical attackers such as Kartana, Kingambit, and Weavile that Slowbro struggles with; the former two remove entry hazards with Defog in case Slowbro is forced to take a Knock Off, while the latter can make use of Future Sight to wallbreak easier.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description: 84 Attack EVs let Muk OHKO a Mega Charizard Y at full with Rock Slide.

sets.name: Pink Blob (Defensive)
sets.description: Thanks to its gargantuan Eviolite-boosted special bulk alongside a lack of relevant weaknesses, Chansey stands firmly as a formidable wall that blanket checks the metagame's special attackers, including Dragapult, Mega Charizard Y, and Volcarona. Toxic lets Chansey whittle them down, especially in conjunction with repeated Seismic Tosses, while Thunder Wave punishes poison-immune foes like Heatran and Toxapex and cripples switch-ins such as Mega Lopunny and Kingambit. Chansey can provide cleric support with Aromatherapy, especially since it can switch into status users like Clodsire and Rotom-W thanks to Natural Cure. However, Stealth Rock can be used if the team lacks another user, and Chansey can do it sufficiently by outlasting common entry hazard removers such as Great Tusk, Tornadus-T, and Landorus-T. Tera Steel allows it to reliably check Tapu Lele, Hatterene, and Tornadus-T, and it prevents Chansey from being poisoned. Chansey is generally reserved for bulkier builds that appreciate its defensive profile and can tolerate its overall passivity. Sturdy walls like Skeledirge, Buzzwole, Skarmory, and Corviknight can cover physical attackers like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Kartana for Chansey. Skeledirge's Unaware helps against setup sweepers like Mega Scizor and Mega Charizard X that attempt to use Chansey as setup fodder, while Corviknight's Defog alleviates Chansey from entry hazard pressure that would overwhelm it easily. Knock Off and Trick absorbers like Clefable, Toxapex, Mega Scizor, and Gholdengo make sure that Chansey can keep its valuable Eviolite; Additionally, Mega Scizor helps deal with Psyshock Tapu Lele, Gholdengo threatens Calm Mind Hatterene, and Calm Mind Clefable overwhelms Heatran—especially if it's paralyzed—all of which are special attackers that can beat Chansey one-on-one.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Mega Gyarados is a powerful sweeper on hyper offense teams thanks to Dragon Dance, Mold Breaker, and its high Attack stat. Mega Gyarados also possesses a valuable defensive typing that helps against foes such as Gholdengo, Volcarona, and Kingambit. Mold Breaker lets Mega Gyarados break through foes such as Tera Fairy Gastrodon and Skeledirge, the latter being a troublesome foe for teammates such as Dragonite and Dragapult. Substitute allows Mega Gyarados to avoid status from foes such as Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Rotom-W while also avoiding revenge killers such as Tapu Lele and Kartana. Alternatively, Earthquake lets Mega Gyarados break through Toxapex and Rotom-W. Taunt can also be used to deny recovery, Haze, and Iron Defense from Toxapex and Skarmory, though it is generally not preferred since it leaves Mega Gyarados vulnerable to Scald burns and revenge killers such as Tapu Lele. Mega Gyarados appreciates dual screen support from Tapu Koko, which allows it to set up more easily. In return, Mega Gyarados can pivot into Ground-type attacks from foes such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk. Mega Gyarados struggles against physical walls such as Skarmory, Ferrothorn, and Buzzwole, so it appreciates teammates such as Volcarona and Iron Valiant handling them. Entry hazard support from teammates such as Landorus-T and Glimmora helps weaken defensive foes such as Tangrowth and Tera Water Landorus-T for Mega Gyarados. Teammates such as Dragonite also appreciate Mega Gyarados weakening defensive foes such as Skeledirge and Ferrothorn so it can clean late-game.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Thanks to Zapdos’s great typing and strong offensive presence, few Pokemon aside from specially defensive walls such as Ting-Lu and Clodsire would want to switch into it. Volt Switch wears down common switch-ins such as Blissey, Heatran, Rotom-W, and Mega Tyranitar, bringing in teammates that punish them like Zamazenta and Kartana. Alternatively, Defog can clear away entry hazards set by Landorus-T and Great Tusk, though Zapdos sets lacking Heavy-Duty Boots struggle to reliably remove hazards. It also misses out on pivoting provided by Volt Switch. Static punishes contact attackers and pivots like Zamazenta, Tornadus-T, Mega Scizor, and Mega Lopunny. If not running Flyinium Z, Tera Flying lets Zapdos break past Landorus-T, Ferrothorn, and Gastrodon with relative ease, all while still threatening Pokemon like Annihilape. Flyinium Z allows Zapdos to muscle through the likes of Annihilape and Gastrodon. The given EV spread allows Zapdos to OHKO Annihilape with Supersonic Skystrike. Teammates like Kingambit, Heatran, and Mega Lopunny appreciate Zapdos putting pressure on their checks, as it threatens Pokemon like Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Toxapex. Without Heavy-Duty Boots, Zapdos is very susceptible to Stealth Rock. As such, entry hazard removers like Great Tusk and Rotom-W are much appreciated. Wallbreakers like Urshifu-R and Garchomp help deal with Zapdos checks such as Clodsire, Ting-Lu, and Heatran. Mega Scizor is a notable partner for Zapdos, as it checks strong, offensive threats such as Mega Diancie and Mega Lopunny, absorbs poison for Zapdos, and forms a good pivoting core with it.

sets.name: Rain
sets.description: Zapdos in rain is a dangerous attacker due to it boosting Hurricane and Thunder’s accuracy, as well as destroying common rain checks like Rotom-W, Ferrothorn, and Tangrowth. Weather Ball under rain allows Zapdos to hit Landorus-T, Clodsire, and Heatran super effectively. Roost allows it to stay healthy throughout the game and consistently be able to check Grass-types like Kartana. Tera Flying allows Zapdos to break through Ferrothorn and Gastrodon after slight chip damage. The given EVs allow Zapdos to outspeed Great Tusk while also maximizing its offensive power to break foes such as Rotom-W, Ferrothorn, and Gastrodon. Pelipper is a mandatory partner for Zapdos, as it sets up rain and can safely pivot out to it. Ferrothorn checks foes such as Weavile and Mega Tyranitar while also setting entry hazards to weaken foes such as Heatran and opposing Ferrothorn. Additionally, Swift Swim Pokemon like Mega Swampert, Floatzel, and Barraskewda can help with Clodsire and Mega Tyranitar, which Zapdos struggles to break through. In return, Zapdos wears down Pokemon that the aforementioned rain wallbreakers would struggle with, such as Ferrothorn, Rotom-W, and Gastrodon, clearing the path for them to clean up after their checks are weakened.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Leveraging an incredible ability in Static accompanied by a powerful Volt Switch and Hurricane, Zapdos serves as a stellar defensive pivot. Zapdos effectively switches into physical attackers such as Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, Kartana, and Great Tusk, discouraging them from attacking by threatening a chance of paralysis. Zapdos can Volt Switch out as it pleases because of common Ground-types like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and the aforementioned Great Tusk fearing its powerful Hurricane. Hidden Power Ice can be used to threaten Ground-types like the aforementioned Landorus-T and Garchomp while additionally hitting Gliscor harder and much more reliably than Hurricane. Carrying Heat Wave is recommended with Hidden Power Ice to maintain the ability to OHKO Kartana. These positive matchups into many Ground-types allow Zapdos to serve as a solid Defog user, but it struggles to beat bulkier Stealth Rock users such as Heatran, Mega Tyranitar, and Clodsire. Alternatively, Zapdos can forgo Defog for Heat Wave, allowing it to threaten Pokemon such as Kingambit, Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, and Gholdengo. Tera Steel is utilized by Zapdos to flip its Rock- and Ice-type weaknesses versus Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar, Weavile, and Mega Diancie as well as check Choice Specs Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele in a pinch. However, it becomes weak to common Ground- and Fighting-type moves from Pokemon it wants to check. Teammates that appreciate the spread of paralysis, such as Mega Medicham, Urshifu-R, and Weavile, naturally pair well with Zapdos. Mega Medicham particularly pairs nicely with it, as Mega Medicham threatens Clodsire while enjoying Zapdos pivoting it into favorable matchups such as Heatran, with Zapdos punishing Tornadus-T and Mega Lopunny looking to revenge kill Mega Medicham in return. Pursuit users like Kingambit and the aforementioned Weavile are useful teammates to assist in chipping down Clodsire as well as punishing Dragapult. Rock-types like Mega Diancie and Mega Tyranitar threaten Zapdos, so teammates that mitigate these weaknesses, like Hippowdon and Gastrodon, are appreciated.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder untill an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Moltres’s main niche comes from its variety of useful qualities making it a prominent defensive Pokemon. It is a defogger that can threaten Gholdengo; a check to common Stealth Rock setters like Great Tusk, Heatran, and Garchomp; and a deterrent to contact attackers like U-turn users, Kartana, and Mega Lopunny. However, its main weakness lies in its overreliance on its Heavy-Duty Boots—although Tera could let it drop its weakness to Rock, Tera is usually better spent on other Pokemon, so Moltres still fears Knock Off from opponents it would otherwise check, like Iron Valiant, Landorus-T, Kartana, and Mega Scizor. Tera Water is used to ease the matchup against rain, becoming a check to common rain abusers like Basculegion-M, Mega Swampert and Barraskewda and threatening to burn them with Flame Body. Tera Ground instead grants a resistance to Stealth Rock and Stone Edge from Choice Scarf Landorus-T and an immunity to Volt Switch from Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Rotom-W and Thunderbolt from Iron Valiant. Mystical Fire is chosen over Flamethrower, as its Special Attack drop is useful to more easily check Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Mega Charizard Y, and Gholdengo. Scorching Sands is used to beat Heatran and also deter physical attackers looking to set up due to its high burn chance. Hurricane allows Moltres to OHKO Great Tusk and Mega Lopunny while heavily denting Volcarona and is useful in general as a powerful STAB option, U-turn allows Moltres to function as a pivot, pivoting out on foes like Heatran and Garganacl, and Toxic allows Moltres to punish Pokemon such as Hippowdon, Ting-Lu, and Garchomp looking to soak up its STAB options. The given EVs allow Moltres to survive two Frustration from Mega Lopunny without Stealth Rock damage. However, there are still many opponents that can pressure Moltres, like Garganacl, Toxapex, and Tapu Koko. Moltres thus pairs well with wallbreakers that can take advantage of such switch-ins to come in, like Tapu Lele or Iron Valiant. Moltres also dislikes having its Heavy-Duty Boots removed, so teammates that can absorb Knock Off are appreciated, including Mega Scizor and Gliscor.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Galarian Moltres serves as a unique setup sweeper on hyper offense teams thanks to its ability to effortlessly set up Nasty Plot against metagame staples such as Tornadus-T and Gholdengo with its solid defensive and offensive profile. Agility allows Galarian Moltres to outpace dangerous revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, and Choice Scarf Kartana. However, Taunt is also a valuable alternative to Agility in order to shut down defensive checks like Haze Toxapex and Unaware Clodsire while also preventing common status spreaders like Landorus-T, Ferrothorn, and Heatran from limiting its sweep. Heavy-Duty Boots negates chip damage from entry hazards and allows Galarian Moltres to set up more reliably. Flyinium Z is used in order to quickly eliminate bulkier threats such as Toxapex and Ferrothorn without risking a miss due to Hurricane's poor accuracy; however, this leaves Galarian Moltres unable to Terastallize against threats such as Tapu Lele. Sitrus Berry is another option that lets Galarian Moltres maintain its health and trigger Berserk twice. Galarian Moltres is a great user of Terastallization, using Tera Steel to set up on its standard checks in Tapu Lele, Toxapex, Tapu Koko, and Clefable. Tera Steel also lets it resist many forms of priority including, but not limited to, Mega Lopunny's and Mega Medicham's Fake Out, Weavile's Ice Shard, and Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch. However, Galarian Moltres's new weaknesses mean that it has a harder time setting up on Mega Lopunny, Heatran, and Landorus-T while also being susceptible to other forms of priority like Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Galarian Moltres enjoys dual screens support to let it set up incredibly easily, so Tapu Koko makes for a great partner as both a solid pivot and dual screens setter. Galarian Moltres can struggle against threats such as Mega Diancie, Iron Valiant, Kingambit, and Mega Tyranitar, so Mega Scizor and Hawlucha make for great partners to handle its checks offensively; in return, Galarian Moltres can break through Pokemon such as Toxapex, Landorus-T, and Gholdengo for them. Fighting-types such as Urshifu-R, Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta are also good partners that can check threats like Heatran, Kingambit, and Garganacl for Galarian Moltres. Iron Valiant, in particular, also synergizes well with dual screens Tapu Koko, making it a fantastic cleaner after Galarian Moltres has broken through the opposing team.

sets.name: Extreme Killer (Dragon Dance)
sets.description: Dragonite's high Attack stat, Dragon Dance, and Tera Normal make it a good user of Extreme Speed, being able to effectively clean late-game. Earthquake helps Dragonite eliminate Normal-resistant Pokemon such as Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Heatran. Roost improves Dragonite's longevity and enables it to acquire multiple boosts against passive opponents. Roost lets Dragonite check Volcarona and rain sweepers such as Barraskewda throughout the entire match. Ice Spinner is another choice that clears the priority-blocking Psychic Terrain and hits Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Dragapult super effectively. Fire Punch can be used to hit bulky Steel-types not weak to Ground such as Corviknight, Mega Scizor, and Ferrothorn. An Adamant nature is usually preferred to maximize Extreme Speed's damage output, but a Jolly nature enables Dragonite to outspeed Tapu Koko and the Normal-immune Dragapult after a single Dragon Dance. Heavy-Duty Boots ensures that Dragonite will always retain Multiscale even if entry hazards are up, but if the team's entry hazard control is good, Silk Scarf is another option that boosts Extreme Speed's power. Dragonite fits well on offensive teams as a priority-using revenge killer and late-game cleaner. Entry hazard support from Great Tusk and Garchomp can help chip down bulky targets such as opposing Great Tusk into range of its attacks. Tapu Lele poses a serious threat to Dragonite, as not only does its Psychic Terrain block Extreme Speed on grounded targets, but with a Choice Scarf it can also outspeed and deal massive damage to Dragonite even after setup, especially if Dragonite has not Terastallized yet. Gholdengo is a good partner, as it can switch in on and threaten Tapu Lele and prevent the opponent from removing entry hazards. Dragonite often struggles against Unaware users such as Dondozo and Skeledirge, so Pokemon that can grab momentum against them are appreciated teammates. Rotom-W and Tapu Koko can come relatively freely on Dondozo and threaten it with a Volt Switch while Heatran and Mega Diancie can switch into and set up Stealth Rock against Skeledirge. Strong wallbreakers like Mega Medicham, Mega Charizard Y, and Zamazenta all take advantage of Pokemon that Dragonite tends to struggle with, such as Dondozo, allowing it to sweep more easily late-game.

sets.name: Cosmic Power
sets.description: Mew is a potent late-game wincon that can bolster its already impressive defensive profile with Cosmic Power, shrugging off most hits after a few boosts. Mew has near-perfect coverage with Stored Power and Body Press, with the latter able to crucially smash Steel- and Dark-types like Kingambit, Ferrothorn, Mega Tyranitar, and Weavile, which would otherwise exploit it. Covert Cloak is a must for Mew to avoid being worn down by Garganacl’s Salt Cure and help against being burned by Scald from the likes of Toxapex. Tera Poison grants Mew an immunity to Toxic, removing the biggest roadblock to its sweep, allowing it to beat the likes of Heatran, Clodsire, and Gliscor. The given EV spread lets Mew outspeed non-Choice Scarf Urshifu-R. Since Mew is very passive while setting up, it is prone to being overwhelmed by Pokemon like Urshifu-R and Garchomp or used as setup fodder by Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Tornadus-T, thus making it crucial that Mew sets up or Tera at the right time. As such, teammates like Toxapex, Skarmory, and Zapdos are much appreciated to help check those Pokemon for Mew. Taunt from Tornadus-T and Heatran and Trick from Choice Specs Iron Valiant shut Mew down, so having teammates like Gliscor, Gholdengo, and Mega Scizor help deal with them. Gholdengo, in particular, is hard for Mew to deal with, as it can boost at a faster rate than Mew while taking a fully stacked-up Stored Power with ease and being immune to Body Press. Therefore, teammates that can threaten or Pursuit trap it such as Garchomp and Kingambit are very appreciated. Toxapex uses Haze to sit on Mew and forces it to Tera to avoid Toxic, thus overwhelming or removing Toxapex with the likes of Gholdengo, Garganacl, and Heatran allow Mew to set up and win.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Thanks to its solid special bulk and excellent longevity between Slack Off and Regenerator, Slowking establishes itself as a passable pivot in the metagame. It can switch into foes like Tornadus-T and non-Toxic Heatran, and it can even scout for Choice Specs users such as Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Lele. Future Sight + Teleport or Chilly Reception lets Slowking support its frail offensive teammates such as Mega Lopunny and Dragapult, giving them safe switch ins and amplifying their wallbreaking prowess afterwards. Teleport is a much more reliable way of pivoting, as its higher PP makes it more valuable in longer games and it provides Slowking's teammates with a safe switch in against Ferrothorn and other Teleport users like Blissey and Slowbro. Alternatively, Chilly Reception's snow helps disrupt weather teams like sun and rain as well as support Ice-type teammates like Kyurem and Weavile with its Defense boost. Tera Fairy improves Slowking's matchup against Dragapult and Tapu Koko and maintains its Fighting resistance against Mega Lopunny, while Tera Dark lets it better stomach Ghost-type attacks from Gholdengo and Dragapult at the cost of being weaker against Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. Both Tera choices importantly prevent Slowking from being Pursuit trapped by Kingambit, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar. Wallbreakers like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, Great Tusk, and Kingambit appreciate Slowking's slow pivoting, with the looming Future Sight pressuring their switch-ins like Toxapex, Buzzwole, and defensive Great Tusk. Moreover, Slowking switches into their revenge killers, notably Nasty Plot Tornadus-T and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Defensive Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and Tangrowth cover foes like Weavile, Tapu Koko, and Kartana, respectively; Ferrothorn and Tangrowth also deal with rain wallbreakers like Mega Swampert and Barraskewda that would otherwise overwhelm Slowking despite its Water resistance, with the latter in particular forming a Regnerator core with Slowking.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description: Galarian Slowking is a unique special wall, reliably using Future Sight against passive Pokemon like Toxapex and Clefable while also checking Pokemon like Walking Wake, Iron Valiant, and Iron Moth. It can also take super effective hits from Dragapult and Gholdengo. Flamethrower hits Steel-types like Kingambit, Gholdengo, and Ferrothorn, while Scald allows Galarian Slowking to spread poison and burn alike, crippling common switch-ins like Toxapex, Dragapult, and Gastrodon. Scald also punishes Ground-types like Landorus-T and Great Tusk. Ice Beam catches Ground-types and Dragonite, but it isn't as reliable as Scald, as it leaves Galarian Slowking unable to hit Heatran. Focus Blast instantly KOes Kingambit on the switch and hits Heatran harder, but it is very unreliable. The given EV spread prevents a 2HKO from Choice Specs Protosynthesis Walking Wake's Draco Meteor. Tera Steel helps Galarian Slowking check Fairy-types like Tapu Lele and Hatterene, while Tera Water improves its Walking Wake and rain matchups. Both also make Galarian Slowking neutral to Pursuit from the likes of Kingambit and Weavile. Future Sight support is highly appreciated by Fighting-types like Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, and Iron Valiant, as it pressures their checks in Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Clodsire. They can pressure Pursuit Kingambit, a major roadblock to Galarian Slowking. Knock Off absorbers like offensive Tornadus-T, Clefable, and Gliscor also work well with Galarian Slowking. The former can form a strong Regenerator core pivoting and gaining information through the game. Entry hazard setters like Ferrothorn and Ting-Lu appreciate Galarian Slowking's ability to cripple common Defoggers like Tornadus-T and Zapdos with Sludge Bomb and Scald. In return, Galarian Slowking likes entry hazards wearing down its checks, namely Kingambit, Heatran, and Gholdengo.

sets.name: Bulky Swords Dance
sets.description: Mega Scizor leverages its great bulk and solid defensive typing to serve as a sturdy check to many Pokemon—including Weavile, Kartana, and Tapu Lele—and a solid wincon as well. U-turn allows it to serve as a pivot: easily switching it out of checks such as Gholdengo, Urshifu-R, and Mega Charizard Y, it brings in teammates like Tapu Koko and Dragapult to deal with them. Close Combat can be used to dispose of Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Heatran much more quickly, greatly denting them on the switch. The given EV spread allows Mega Scizor to survive two Close Combats from Mega Lopunny after Stealth Rock and outspeed uninvested Heatran, with the HP and Special Defense EVs helping it check Tapu Lele. Mega Scizor's pivot support is extremely valuable to Pokemon such as Tapu Koko, Rotom-W, and Zamazenta, which all also appreciate how well it exploits defensive Pokemon such as Clodsire, Ferrothorn, and Landorus-T. Rotom-W forms a strong VoltTurn core with Mega Scizor as well, with both pivoting out on their checks and racking up solid chip damage over time. Nasty Plot Tornadus-T appreciates Mega Scizor pressuring specially defensive walls and offensive Pokemon like Weavile and Clodsire, letting it go all-in as an offensive wallbreaker with ease. Mega Scizor wearing down Rotom-W and Heatran is also particularly useful for Tornadus-T, as these Pokemon can heavily damage or cripple Tornadus-T in one way or another. Mega Scizor being completely countered by Gholdengo mandates a Pursuit trapper like Weavile or Kingambit to pressure it. Skeledirge also hard counters Mega Scizor, encouraging the aforementioned teammates as well as Garganacl and Heatran.

sets.name: Swords Dance + 3 Attacks
sets.description: This set takes on a much more offensive role, using its solid defensive typing for easy entry points against Pokemon like Weavile and Kingambit, setting up, and threatening the vast majority of the metagame with its strong Technician-boosted attacks. Close Combat KOes Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn, as well as providing a strong neutral hit against Rotom-W. Dual Wingbeat hits Clodsire and Toxapex for reliable neutral damage and also hits Zamazenta super effectively, Knock Off is an alternative to hit Gholdengo reliably and remove items like Leftovers from Rotom-W and Heavy-Duty Boots from Tornadus-T, Skeledirge, and Volcarona. This allows a teammate or Mega Scizor to wear them down much more easily. Knock Off is especially relevant in Rotom-W's case, as removing Leftovers makes it easier to put into KO range of +2 Close Combat. Running Knock Off makes Toxapex a much worse matchup, however, so Pokemon like Great Tusk and Tapu Koko that can pressure it are appreciated. Sand Tomb can be used to reliably beat Clodsire, Toxapex, and Gholdengo, preventing them from reliably checking it. Offensive Mega Scizor fits much better on hyper offense teams, which appreciate its incredibly valuable—though short-term—defensive utility. Grimmsnarl is a perfect teammate, providing dual screens to let it set up against foes like Great Tusk, Dragonite, and Landorus-T; it also pivots Mega Scizor in and appreciates it baiting in Gholdengo, which prevents Grimmsnarl from pivoting as effectively. Gholdengo itself is also a notable partner, as it appreciates Mega Scizor dispatching the most popular Dark-types in Weavile and Kingambit. Entry hazards from suicide leads like Landorus-T and Garchomp allow Mega Scizor to clean late-game, as its foes must be chipped before any sweeping is done. Entry hazards particularly help in wearing down checks like Urshifu-R and bulkier Garchomp sets. Mega Scizor struggles against bulky Steel-resistant Pokemon like Rotom-W and Volcarona; Dragonite and Dragapult can take care of the latter, switching into Volcarona to set up as it switches into Mega Scizor, whereas Great Tusk can remove Leftovers from the former, making it easier for Mega Scizor to dispatch with +2 Close Combat. Physically defensive Unaware walls in Skeledirge and Dondozo completely wall Mega Scizor, so offensive Pokemon that can bait in or wear down these foes, including Iron Valiant, make for solid partners.

sets.name: Pink Blob
sets.description: Blissey's immense special bulk, useful utility moves, and reliable recovery allow it to function as a niche specially defensive pivot, as it checks threats such as Choice Specs Dragapult and Mega Charizard Y. Seismic Toss allows Blissey to pressure anything that isn't a Ghost-type with meaningful damage. Toxic is the preferred option to cripple Pokemon like Mega Charizard Y and Volcarona. Thunder Wave can also be used to annoy fast threats like Tornadus-T and Iron Valiant. It also allows Blissey to status Steel-types like Kingambit, Heatran, and Kartana. Teleport allows Blissey to safely pivot in teammates like Dragapult, Zamazenta, and Mega Medicham. However, Blissey is an acceptable Stealth Rock user if no other fits on your team. Shadow Ball can be considered as a niche option to break Dragapult's Substitutes and chip offensive Gholdengo, but it usually isn't worth dropping other moves. Tera Fairy gives Blissey a Fighting resistance in exchange for negligible Poison and Steel weaknesses, and it reduces the damage it takes from Pursuit users like Kingambit, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar. This should be used if Blissey absolutely has to take on a Fighting- or Dark-type like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, or Weavile. Blissey's defensive profile makes it a liability into certain Ghost-types, specifically Dragon Dance Dragapult and Gholdengo. Kingambit is a great option that deals with the former two threats while also benefitting from Blissey bringing it in safely with Teleport. Other wallbreakers like Tapu Lele, Dragapult, Mega Charizard Y, and Mega Medicham also appreciate pivot support and benefit from Blissey spreading Thunder Wave. A switch-in to powerful physical attackers, like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, Mega Medicham, and Kingambit, is necessary. Options like Toxapex, Slowbro, Skarmory, and Great Tusk can help out on this front. Knock Off is irritating for Blissey, as losing its Heavy-Duty Boots is quite detrimental to its pivoting efforts. Options such as Flyinium Z Tornadus-T and Gliscor can help out in this regard.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description: Mega Tyranitar serves as a valuable Stealth Rock setter and Pursuit trapper due to its powerful STAB moves, great bulk, and Rock / Dark typing, allowing it to handle Ghost- and Flying-types well. Stone Edge threatens common Defoggers in Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Rotom-W to ensure its Stealth Rock stays on the field. Crunch dents Pokemon like Dragapult and Gholdengo while doing sizable damage to Gastrodon and Ferrothorn. Alternatively, Superpower can be used over Crunch to immediately threaten Kingambit, Ting-Lu, and Ferrothorn, but it leaves Mega Tyranitar unable to pressure Pokemon like Gholdengo, Clodsire, and Reuniclus. Pursuit traps Pokemon like Tapu Lele, Dragapult, Tornadus-T, and Gholdengo. 108 Speed EVs allow Mega Tyranitar to outspeed Gholdengo. Mega Tyranitar's middling defensive typing leaves it extremely vulnerable to Pokemon such as Mega Lopunny, Great Tusk, and Zamazenta. As such, defensive Pokemon like Zapdos, Gholdengo, and Toxapex pair well with Mega Tyranitar, as they cover the threats it would struggle with. Toxapex in particular appreciates Mega Tyranitar trapping Heatran and Gholdengo with Pursuit, after which it can then stack Toxic Spikes. This, along with Mega Tyranitar's Stealth Rock, wears down each other's checks like Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Zamazenta. Mega Tyranitar also appreciates Pokemon that can deal with Ground-types, such as Zapdos, Tornadus-T, and Tangrowth. Fighting-type partners such as Iron Valiant and Zamazenta greatly appreciate Mega Tyranitar removing Pokemon like Gholdengo and Reuniclus. Mega Tyranitar's sand enables Excadrill, which is a great offensive partner for it. Excadrill is able to snipe Pokemon like Mega Diancie and Kingambit, while Tyranitar deals with Flying-types like Zapdos and Mega Charizard Y in return. Mega Tyranitar can also chip Pokemon like Rotom-W and Landorus-T, which enables Excadrill break past them more easily.

sets.name: Rain Setter
sets.description: Pelipper is a staple pick on rain teams thanks to its ability, Drizzle. Its physical bulk combined with Scald lets it check and potentially cripple foes such as Mega Lopunny, Mega Scizor, and Great Tusk. Hurricane is an alternative to Defog on teams that use Tornadus-T for entry hazard control, which offers better neutral coverage and the ability to hit foes such as Tangrowth and Tera Grass Heatran. Pelipper also operates as a slow pivot with U-turn, which is greatly appreciated by the team's wallbreakers to ensure that they can enter the field safely. Tera Ground offers an Electric immunity for threats such as Tapu Koko, whereas Tera Steel offers a strong defensive typing, letting Pelipper check Pokemon like Extreme Speed Dragonite in a pinch. As the premier rain setter, Pokemon that rely on rain to boost their power or operate effectively within it, such as Mega Swampert, Floatzel, Barraskewda, and Urshifu-R, make for common teammates. Mega Swampert offers a valuable Electric immunity for Pelipper, checking foes such as Tapu Koko. Tornadus-T can provide entry hazard control with Defog, letting Pelipper enter the field and summon rain without having to fear taking hazard damage. Ferrothorn takes advantage of Pelipper's typing and ability to form a solid defensive core and provide a robust blanket check for opposing rain. In return, Pelipper alleviates Ferrothorn's massive Fire weakness by setting rain, and it can check threats that Ferrothorn fails to cover, such as Mega Lopunny.

sets.name: Defensive Magic Bounce
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Mega Medicham is a tremendously strong wallbreaker due to Pure Power, strong STAB moves, and coverage. Fake Out lets Mega Medicham chip down and revenge kill Pokemon like Mega Lopunny, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Koko. It also can let Mega Medicham stall out rain, Toxic, and Terrain on foes, all while putting opponents into range for one of its stronger attacks safely. Ice Punch lets Mega Medicham get rid of Landorus-T and Dragonite, which can enable it to freely use its STAB moves. Bullet Punch can be used to snipe Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Mega Diancie, and Weavile, and it also removes revenge killers like Tapu Koko and Mega Lopunny after chip damage. Thunder Punch can be used to hit Slowbro, and in tandem with Electric Terrain, it can 2HKO Pokemon like Gholdengo and Victini. Alternatively, Thief can be used to immediately damage the aforementioned Pokemon, so it can use its STAB moves more. Due to Mega Medicham’s frailty and mediocre Speed tier, it is easily revenge killed. Defensive partners like Gholdengo, Ting-Lu, and Ferrothorn help check threats like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Dragapult. Knock Off and Pursuit users like Kingambit and Weavile also support Mega Medicham, as they break through Psychic- and Ghost-type Pokemon Mega Medicham struggle with, such as Slowbro, Victini, Gholdengo and Skeledirge, allowing it to consistently use its STAB attacks. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Ferrothorn benefit Mega Medicham, as it forces a lot of switches and entry hazards wear down checks quickly. Tapu Koko is a good partner for Mega Medicham, as it handles Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Slowbro reliably and powers up Mega Medicham's Thunder Punch. Tapu Lele can also be a good partner for Mega Medicham, as it powers up Zen Headbutt to insane levels, but blocking Fake Out and Bullet Punch from being used can be problematic. Pokemon like Volcarona and Kartana appreciate Torandus-T, Skeledirge, Clodsire, and Gholdengo being pressured constantly by Mega Medicham, enabling them to wreak havoc once the checks are removed or chipped.

sets.name: Rain Wallbreaker
sets.description: Floatzel is an incredible wallbreaker on rain teams, making use of its decent Attack stat powered by its Choice Band. Low Kick hits Ferrothorn and Ice Spinner hits Dragapult and Dragonite more reliably. However, because of Tera Water, its Water-type moves are all boosted considerably, so coverage is often unnecessary. Aqua Jet gives Floatzel priority outside of rain against weakened targets such as Tapu Koko, Iron Valiant, and Mega Lopunny, and it bypasses Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Tornadus-T and Zapdos all appreciate Floatzel's offensive capabilities, as it deals with wallbreakers such as Dragapult, Mega Diancie, Gholdengo, Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Iron Valiant. Zapdos can reliably check Water-types that counter Floatzel like Slowbro and Dondozo. Tornadus-T can weaken and cripple Floatzel checks in Rotom-W, Dondozo, and Ferrothorn, as Knock Off removes Leftovers from them, making it easier for Floatzel to wallbreak. Offensive partners like Manaphy and Mega Swampert can overwhelm those same Water-resistant Pokemon as well as Dragonite. Ferrothorn can check priority users such as the aforementioned Dragonite and Kingambit, alleviating Floatzel's weakness to them.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Gastrodon finds itself a valuable role in National Dex primarily off its invaluable Water and Electric immunities, allowing it to handle terrifying rain sweepers such as Floatzel and Mega Swampert and answer Rotom-W perfectly. Scald lets Gastrodon threaten a burn against otherwise safe switch-ins such as Ferrothorn and Dragonite. Toxic better threatens defensive Pokemon such as opposing Gastrodon, Skeledirge, and Tornadus-T. Earthquake threatens Pokemon like Heatran, Clodsire, and Gholdengo. Relaxed should be selected as Gastrodon's nature if using Earthquake to not lower its damage output; Bold should be used otherwise. Tera Fairy can be used in a pinch to grant Gastrodon a resistance to Fighting against Urshifu-R and Barraskweda and a Dark resistance against Kingambit. The given EV spread maximizes Gastrodon's physical bulk to better take on the likes of Floatzel, Mega Swampert, and Urshifu-R. Gastrodon fits best on balance and bulky offense teams, which appreciate its defensive qualities while being able to supplement its passivity with offensive wallbreakers. Pokemon such as Tornadus-T and Gholdengo can switch into Grass-type coverage from Pokemon like Kartana and Ferrothorn; In return, Gastrodon provides entry hazard support to wear down answers such as Mega Tyranitar, Kingambit, and Clodsire. Strong, fast wallbreakers like Mega Diancie, Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta love having Gastrodon as a fallback measure against the myriad of Water-type revenge killers on rain such as Floatzel and Mega Swampert. If Gastrodon opts to use Spikes, it likes having Stealth Rock setters such as Heatran and Mega Diancie as partners to form an effective entry hazard-stacking core.

sets.name: Offensive Stealth Rock
sets.description: Garchomp serves as an excellent wallbreaker that possesses great defensive utility, having an Electric-type immunity and being a check to Pokemon like Heatran and Volcarona. Outrage with Dragonium Z muscles through Pokemon like Great Tusk, Tangrowth, and Ting-Lu. Garchomp fits best on offensive teams; Pokemon like Volcarona, Mega Charizard Y, and Tapu Koko benefit from it breaking through Pokemon like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Dragonite. Tapu Koko makes a stellar partner because it can pivot on Garchomp targets in Clodsire, Gastrodon, and Gliscor. In return, Tapu Koko threatens Corviknight and Slowbro, two major roadblocks for Garchomp. Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Kingambit can pressure revenge killers such as Iron Valiant, Weavile, and Dragapult thanks to their strong priority while taking several attacks from them. Rotom-W switches into Pokemon that threaten Garchomp such as Great Tusk and Tornadus-T. Garchomp can take care of Pokemon Rotom-W pivots out on such as Gastrodon, Ferrothorn, and Gholdengo.

sets.name: TankChomp
sets.description: Garchomp possesses great role compression and is a good check to contact attackers like Mega Scizor, Dragonite, and Mega Lopunny. Toxic can cripple switch-ins such as Landorus-T, Tangrowth, and Rotom-W. Dragon Tail can stop any setup attempts from Volcarona, Mega Scizor, and Dragonite lacking Ice Spinner and can wear down Pokemon like Corviknight, Rotom-W, and Landorus-T. Alternatively, Flamethrower can rip through Pokemon like Kartana, Mega Scizor, and Ferrothorn. Tera Ghost lets Garchomp spinblock Great Tusk and switch into Fighting-type moves from Pokemon like Mega Medicham and Zamazenta, while Tera Water grants resistances to Gholdengo's Make It Rain and Ice- and Water-type moves from Weavile, Floatzel, and Urshifu-R as well as neutrality to Fairy-type attacks from Iron Valiant and Mega Diancie. Tera Steel gives it a Toxic immunity and improves Garchomp's matchup against Tapu Lele, Kartana, and Dragapult. The given Speed EVs with a Jolly Nature allows Garchomp to outspeed Timid Gholdengo, while maximizing its physical bulk. Teammates like Mega Scizor, Gholdengo, and Volcarona can cover Garchomp's Ice and Fairy weaknesses and threaten out a majority of Garchomp checks such as Iron Valiant, Weavile, and Mega Diancie. In return, Garchomp can switch into Rock- and Fire-type Pokemon like Heatran, Mega Tyranitar, and Volcarona. Knock Off Kingambit and Weavile support Garchomp by crippling common Defoggers like Tornadus-T and Landorus-T.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Mega Garchomp is a passable wallbreaker thanks to its its staggering Attack stat alongside Swords Dance, busting through bulky Pokemon like Garganacl, Hippowdon, and Toxapex. Its typing and solid natural bulk grant it it multiple setup opportunities, such as in the face of Volcarona, Mega Tyranitar, non-Toxic Heatran, and Zapdos. Scale Shot's multi-hit nature makes it effective against Dragonite and Substitute users like Kyurem and Serperior, as well as offensive teams supported by Cyclizar's Shed Tail. Most importantly, the Speed boost lets Mega Garchomp outpace would-be revenge killers like Dragapult, Iron Valiant, Tapu Koko, and—if it decides not to Mega Evolve yet—Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, allowing it to potentially clean up late-game. Fire Fang hits Skarmory, Corviknight, Tangrowth, and cleanly OHKOes Ferrothorn at +2. Mega Garchomp works well on offensive teams, ranging from offense to hyper offense. Pivots like Tapu Koko, Dragapult, Tornadus-T, and Victini give Mega Garchomp easy entry, bringing it onto their switch-ins such as Clodsire, Toxapex, Heatran, and Skeledirge, respectively. Tapu Fini provides Misty Terrain to prevent Mega Garchomp from being crippled by the aforementioned walls—at the cost of weakening its Scale Shot, however—as well as a switch-in to Ice Shard users like Baxcalibur and Weavile that can revenge kill Mega Garchomp easily. Dual screens and Shed Tail support from Tapu Koko or Grimmsnarl and Cyclizar give Mega Garchomp more setup opportunities. Setup sweepers such as Volcarona, Iron Valiant, and Dragonite enjoy Mega Garchomp pressuring foes like Skeledirge and Toxapex. Special wallbreakers like the aforementioned Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Dragapult help against physical walls such as Dondozo and Tera Water Skeledirge that Mega Garchomp struggles with; Tapu Lele's Psychic Terrain also prevents Mega Garchomp's sweep from being cut short by priority attacks from the likes of Weavile, Mega Lopunny, and Kingambit.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Hippowdon is a bulky Ground-type wall and Stealth Rock setter able to switch into threatening offensive Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, Tapu Koko, and Mega Charizard Y. It can find plenty of time to set up Stealth Rock and spread chip damage with Toxic and its ability Sand Stream. Sand Stream also allows Hippowdon to disrupt opposing weather, which is bolstered by its positive matchup against every other weather setter. Toxic notably nets a ton of chip damage on Defoggers attempting to get rid of Hippowdon's Stealth Rock and Ground-Immune Pokemon switching into Earthquake, such as Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, and Mega Charizard Y. Hippowdon can Terastallize into the Steel typing to avoid Toxic in addition to Grass-, Water-, and Ice-type attacks while maintaining its sand immunity and Stealth Rock resistance. Even beyond the simple type matchup chart changes, it allows Hippowdon to more easily check its targets such as Tornadus-T, Tapu Lele, Zapdos, and Mega Diancie. Maximum Special Defense EVs are ran due to Hippowdon having more valuable special targets than physical, namely the aforementioned Pokemon. Mega Lopunny and Tornadus-T appreciate Hippowdon's presence, as it checks both Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Zapdos while setting up Stealth Rock to help wear down their checks. Defensively, Hippowdon supports Pokemon such as Garganacl and Skarmory; Garganacl appreciates the sand and its attached benefits and Skarmory appreciates the sturdy Ground-type anchor and special wall. Hippowdon struggles to fend off strong physical attackers like Kingambit, Mega Scizor, Kartana, and Mega Gyarados. For this reason, it pairs exquisitely with strong physical walls such as Skarmory and Buzzwole. Hippowdon also suffers from a Spikes vulnerability, meaning it appreciates Defog support from Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Zapdos.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Weavile's potent STAB combination and great offensive stats give it an excellent place in the National Dex metagame, with its ability to threaten teams offensively and Pursuit trap Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Galarian Slowking, easing matchups for teammates such as Sneasler and Tapu Lele. Triple Axel threatens OHKOs on offensive Pokemon such as Mega Charizard Y, Kartana, and Sneasler and 2HKOs on physically defensive Ferrothorn after minimal chip damage. Knock Off is a powerful STAB option that heavily damages switch-ins predicting Triple Axel such as Rotom-W, Heatran, and Alomomola. Ice Shard gives Weavile some form of speed control and helps finish off weakened foes that normally threaten it such as Mega Lopunny, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Koko, as well as boosted Pokemon such as Tera Flying Unburden Sneasler and Tera Grass Volcarona. Furthermore, Weavile's longevity, and therefore its offensive pressure, is limited by its weakness to Stealth Rock, so Defoggers such as Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Tornadus-T are all very helpful. Mega Scizor's U-turn and Alomomola's Flip Turn are also appreciated to bring Weavile in safely, due to its frailty. In return, Weavile helps these Pokemon out by getting rid of thorns such as Great Tusk, Gliscor, and Mega Charizard Y, letting Scizor have a larger role offensively, as well as removing Pokemon like Gholdengo and Zapdos for Alomomola, which can use Alomomola as setup fodder and threaten an OHKO with Thunderbolt or Volt Switch to gain momentum, respectively. Mega Medicham and Iron Valiant are both excellent partners for Weavile, taking care of Toxapex, as well as bulky Steel-types such as Heatran and Ferrothorn, with Weavile Pursuit trapping Gholdengo for both of them or forcing it to Terastallize. Although Tera Dark is the preferred Tera type in order to mitigate Weavile's weakness to Stealth Rock and boost Knock Off to absurd levels, Tera Ice can also be used, making Ice Shard an extremely threatening priority move, able to even 2HKO Pokemon that pressure Weavile such as Tapu Koko and Iron Valiant.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Weavile's great Speed and Attack paired with Swords Dance makes it one of the most versatile Pokemon in the metagame, being able to wallbreak, revenge kill, and clean late-game. Most of Weavile's checks, such as Urshifu-R, Kingambit, and Heatran, aren't long-term checks and don't like losing their item. It also requires a minimal amount of chip damage on Pokemon like Buzzwole, Iron Hands, and Toxapex to effectively break them. Triple Axel is used for the larger damage output, but Ice Spinner can be used for a consistent and accurate STAB move. Icicle Crash avoids residual damage from contact abilities like Iron Barbs while also avoiding Static, Flame Body, and Rocky Helmet. Knock Off is usually preferred, as it can remove items from Toxapex and Ferrothorn and support Weavile's team, but Darkinium Z paired with Throat Chop allows Weavile to nuke its checks, mainly Toxapex, Corviknight, and Ferrothorn. Tera Dark removes Weavile's weakness to Bullet Punch from Mega Scizor while also propelling Knock Off's damage to nearly unstoppable levels. Pivot support from the likes of Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Tapu Koko helps Weavile by bringing it safely onto the field while also allowing it to set up, making it more consistent. Magnezone works well with Weavile, as it can trap and remove Mega Scizor, Ferrothorn, and Corviknight for it. In return, Weavile pressures Ground-types like Landorus-T and Garchomp. Weavile also appreciates being paired with strong wallbreakers that share checks with it such as Kartana, Tapu Lele, and Mega Mawile, as they can overwhelm them throughout the game. Weavile enjoys Spikes support from Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and Garchomp, as it forces chip damage on its checks, such as Mega Scizor, Toxapex, and Iron Hands.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Magnezone carves itself a niche thanks to Magnet Pull, which allows it to trap and remove Steel-types such as Mega Scizor, Kartana, Ferrothorn, and Skarmory, potentially forcing the latter three to Terastallize so teammates such as Kartana and Tapu Lele can beat them. Volt Switch lets Magnezone maintain momentum while eliminating foes such as Skarmory and chipping Heatran, which cannot be trapped and removed consistently. Alternatively, Tera Blast + Tera Fighting lets Magnezone remove Kingambit, potentially forcing it to Terastallize as well. Hidden Power Fire hits foes such as the aforementioned Mega Scizor, Kartana, and Ferrothorn. Toxic is another alternative that punishes switch-ins such as Gastrodon, Ting-Lu, and Hippowdon, though it can be difficult to justify over other alternatives, as it hinders Magnezone's effectiveness as a trapper. Magnezone should only Terastallize when it can trap and eliminate Kingambit, since teammates such as Dragapult and Dragonite take advantage of Tera better. The given EV spread allows Magnezone to survive an unboosted Sacred Sword from Kartana. Teammates such as Dragonite and Kartana appreciate Magnezone removing foes such as Skarmory and Ferrothorn, allowing them to sweep easier. The former can also safely switch into Ground-type attacks for Magnezone, while the latter threatens troublesome Ground-types such as Hippowdon and Gastrodon. Teammates such as Dragapult and Landorus-T provide pivoting support for Magnezone, granting it free entry against foes such as Skarmory and Kingambit to ease prediction. Dragapult in particular appreciates Magnezone trapping and removing Kingambit, allowing it to sweep without fear of being Pursuit trapped.

sets.name: Hazards Support
sets.description: Thanks to its respectable bulk and fantastic passive longevity with Poison Heal, Gliscor occupies a fantastic niche on defensive teams. Its lack of use for its item slot after its activation combined with its Spikes immunity allows Gliscor to withstand weaker Knock Off attempts from Tornadus-T, Toxapex, and Ferrothorn. Gliscor can use its longevity to act as an excellent Defog user, as it can outlast common Stealth Rock setters such as Landorus-T, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl. Alternatively, Gliscor can opt for Stealth Rock if its team prefers it over Defog. Roost keeps Gliscor healthy alongside Poison Heal, allowing it to drain the PP of moves such as Heatran's Magma Storm and Garganacl's Salt Cure. Toxic allows Gliscor to pressure common entry hazard setters and Ground-immune Pokemon, such as Landorus-T, Ting-Lu, Rotom-W, and Tornadus-T. It also allows Gliscor to cripple offensive Pokemon such as Dragapult and Tapu Lele in a pinch. Tera Fairy gives Gliscor a generally solid defensive typing with few weaknesses, although at the cost of its Spikes immunity. The given HP EVs maximize Gliscor's recovery from Poison Heal and special bulk, with the remainder in Speed to outspeed Rotom-W. Gliscor fits best on defensive teams that appreciate its immense survivability and great support options. As such, Gliscor pairs well with sturdy physical and special walls, such as Skeledirge, Skarmory, Buzzwole, and Clodsire, since its relatively unremarkable bulk puts it at risk of being overwhelmed often. In return, it can switch into weak attacks with problematic secondary effects, such as Toxapex's Scald and Garganacl's Salt Cure, as well as help teammates keep their held items by absorbing Knock Off. Pokemon weak to entry hazards such as Nasty Plot Tornadus-T and Garganacl pair well with Gliscor's Defog support, while they act as threatening late-game wincons after Gliscor has worn down their checks. Gliscor pairs exceptionally well with Toxapex, as they form an incredibly sturdy pivoting core due to their incredible passive recovery.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance Gliscor is an incredibly potent wincon, using its incredible longevity and solid bulk to effortlessly setup on passive Pokemon such as Landorus-T, Toxapex, and Clefable. Facade provides Gliscor with an excellent alternative move to hit Ground-resistant and -immune Pokemon such as Skarmory, Zapdos, and Buzzwole, with its ample PP ensuring that it can outstall their recovery PP if necessary. Roost provides Gliscor with instant recovery, allowing it to check Pokemon like Mega Diancie and Heatran. The given EVs allow Gliscor to fulfill this purpose with Special Defense investment, with the HP maximizing its recovery from Poison Heal. Tera Fairy allows Gliscor to leverage a typing with few exploitable weaknesses, given Steel-types such as Kingambit and Gholdengo fear its Earthquake, while Tera Water improves Gliscor's matchup against Pokemon like Volcarona and Urshifu-R. However, it comes with more exploitable weaknesses, given the prominence of Tapu Koko, Rotom-W, and Ferrothorn. Gliscor fits best on balance and fat teams, which appreciate its ability to tear through opposing defensive cores while providing enough of a defensive backbone in return to facilitate this. Pokemon like Toxapex, Skarmory, and Gholdengo can exploit Gliscor's temporary checks such as Great Tusk, Skarmory, and Buzzwole, generating progress of their own. On the flip side, revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny and Dragapult can threaten offensive teams, given Gliscor's tendency to be overwhelmed when facing multiple strong wallbreakers. Gliscor appreciates Pursuit support from Mega Tyranitar or Kingambit, as it removes Gliscor's few true walls in Tera Ghost Rotom-W and Air Balloon Gholdengo.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Blessed with great typing alongside Levitate, Rotom-W is an exceptional defensive pivot, able to switch in and cripple physical attackers with Will-O-Wisp, as well as pivoting out of them safely using Volt Switch in order to bring in teammates. Furthermore, offensive teams appreciate its ability to check a multitude of threats, such as Mega Scizor, Mega Swampert, and Heatran. Common entry hazard setters such as Hisuian Samurott and Great Tusk value Rotom-W's STAB combination of Hydro Pump + Volt Switch, which naturally hits most hazard removers of the tier such as Great Tusk, Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Tornadus-T for super effective damage, threatening them and keeping up hazards. This also helps teammates such as Urshifu-R, Mega Lopunny, and Mega Diancie wallbreak more easily, as the added chip helps in breaking down their checks. Pain Split is Rotom-W's main form of recovery, allowing it to keep itself healthy throughout a match, although it is shaky due to its inconsistency. Defog is also an option, further facilitating bringing frail teammates in safely; however, Rotom-W struggles to threaten the premier Defog blocker in Gholdengo, although it can pivot out of it with Volt Switch. Due to Dragon-types' natural resistance to Water- and Electric-type moves, Fairy- and Ice-types such as Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Weavile are extremely helpful in forcing progress against them. Rotom-W also struggles against Grass-types such as Kartana and Ferrothorn, which Volcarona, Mega Scizor, and Mega Charizard Y help threaten, with Mega Scizor notably forming a powerful VoltTurn core with Rotom-W. Tera Steel is the preferred Tera type for Rotom-W, granting it a number of useful resistances such as to Baxcalibur's Glaive Rush and Icicle Spear as well as Fairy-type STAB moves from Mega Diancie, Tapu Lele, and Iron Valiant. Tera Steel also grants an immunity to Toxic from Pokemon like Clodsire, Gliscor, and Toxapex, which would otherwise severely dampen Rotom-W's lifespan. Tera Ghost is another great option in order to spinblock Great Tusk, wall Swords Dance Gliscor, and, in a pinch, gain an immunity to Fighting-type STAB moves from Pokemon like Zamazenta, Urshifu-R, Great Tusk, and Sneasler.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Rotom-W functions as a shockingly potent pivot, as a lightning-quick Volt Switch allows it to reliably create big surges of momentum for teammates. Will-O-Wisp reliably chips down bulkier threats like Mega Scizor and Garchomp while also surprising faster physical attackers such as Mega Lopunny. Thunder Wave is an option that can pour a cold water onto a sea of speedy sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Swords Dance Kartana, slowing them down. Trick stifles walls like Ferrothorn and Gastrodon who could otherwise stem the tide of Rotom-W’s momentum. Choice Scarf Rotom-W should not be Terastalizing in most cases, but a Steel or Ghost typing can be situationally useful against prominent metagame forces such as Great Tusk and Tapu Lele. Other pivots such as Mega Scizor, Tornadus-T, and Victini can create formidable VoltTurn cores with Rotom-W. Victini in particular deals with Grass-types like Ferrothorn and Kartana, while Rotom-W can threaten physically defensive walls such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk. Strong wallbreakers like Heatran, Iron Valiant, and Mega Medicham pair swimmingly with Rotom-W, as they plow through common defensive staples such as Gastrodon and Ferrothorn and benefit from Rotom-W pivoting them into advantageous positions.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Heatran serves as an effective defensive pivot into Pokemon such as Tapu Lele, Tornadus-T, Victini, Mega Scizor lacking Close Combat, Volcarona, and Gholdengo. Magma Storm allows Heatran to trap and remove defensive Pokemon, such as Zapdos, Toxapex, and Skeledirge. Taunt allows Heatran to deny recovery from Pokemon such as Gastrodon, Clodsire, and Zapdos, making trapping them much more efficient, though it has to Terastallize for the former two. Earth Power provides consistent damage versus Pokemon such as Clodsire, Toxapex, and Gastrodon while also allowing Heatran to deal damage without running the risk of missing Magma Storm, particularly on its trapped opponents. Tera Grass allows Heatran to invalidate typical counterplay such as Gastrodon and Clodsire while also avoiding being revenge killed by Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk. Taunt further bolsters Heatran's effective use of Tera, as it can avoid one of its only potential flaws in becoming vulnerable to Toxic. Heatran can also use Toxic itself to threaten Pokemon using it to set up, such as Garchomp and Dragonite while reducing longevity of Pokemon such as Pelipper, Mega Swampert, and opposing Terastallized Heatran. Tera Grass in conjunction with Flash Fire gives Heatran a unique defensive profile that lets it wall Pokemon such as Mega Charizard Y and opposing Heatran. Heatran must be careful with Tera usage, as Tera Grass can leave it vulnerable to Pokemon such as Volcarona and Tornadus-T. The given EV spread allows Heatran to outspeed uninvested Gholdengo while maximizing special bulk. Electric-types such as Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Rotom-W appreciate Heatran’s ability to bait and remove popular Ground-types once Terastallized, such as Landorus-T, Clodsire, and Gastrodon, as well as heavily chippping Garchomp. Teammates such as Urshifu-R, Dragapult, and Mega Lopunny appreciate Heatran's ability to check Tapu Lele, taking its often choice locked STAB attacks and setting Stealth Rock or firing off a Magma Storm to force progress, benefitting its teammates. Pokemon such as Dragonite and Garchomp can benefit Heatran defensively with both punishing physical attackers such as Mega-Lopunny while also capitalizing on its wallbreaking potential. Heatran is also able to bait and eliminate Tera Fairy Skeledirge for these aforementioned teammates. Rotom-W defensively supports Heatran by preventing it from immediately Terastallizing to beat Clodsire, opposing Rotom-W, and Landorus-T if not desired, providing a safe switch. Heatran struggles to stay healthy in certain matchups versus offensive entry hazard-stacking teams that deny it from coming in freely without seriously chipping itself, so Defoggers like Tornadus-T benefit Heatran while also providing a Ground immunity. Heatran can take advantage of Choice-locked Grass types such as Rillaboom and Kartana when they are trying to hit Rotom-W, and Tornadus-T particularly likes Heatran's ability to check Zapdos and Tapu Koko. Heatran appreciates Pokemon who can soak up Fighting-type moves such as Great Tusk and Tangrowth as Heatran tends to invite in particularly strong revenge killers like Mega-Lopunny and opposing Great Tusk.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Thanks to its unique typing and the combination of Magma Storm, Taunt, and Toxic, Heatran acts as an offensive wallbreaker capable of trapping and remove Pokemon like Clodsire and Toxapex for its teammates. Heatran's fantastic typing also allows it to check Pokemon like Tornadus-T, non-Close Combat or Sand Tomb Mega Scizor, and Tapu Lele. Leftovers gives Heatran longevity and consistency in its role, while Air Balloon lets it check itself and avoid Earthquake from common switch-ins like Garchomp, Gastrodon, and Gliscor. Firium Z allows Heatran to nuke the aforementioned Gliscor and Clodsire. While it doesn't help Heatran offensively, Tera Grass is its best Tera type; it gives it a resistance to Earthquake and takes advantage of the aforementioned Ground-types while also allowing it to be a nightmare for rain teams, as it can now spread Toxic and chip foes on rain very easily. Pivots like Tornadus-T, Tapu Koko, and Rotom-W makes great partners, as they lure Steel-types like Ferrothorn, Corviknight, and Mega Scizor, letting Heatran threaten them with a KO. It also appreciates Pokemon that share checks with it, such as Dragapult, Tornadus-T, and Gholdengo, as Heatran can cripple these common checks, namely Toxapex, Mega Tyranitar, and Gastrodon. Knock Off users like Toxapex and Tornadus-T remove Clodsire's and Toxapex's items, making them less consistent at checking Heatran in the long run.

sets.name: Stored Power
sets.description: Cresselia serves as a potentially terrifying setup sweeper, using its naturally titanic mixed bulk alongside Terastallization to accumulate multiple Calm Mind boosts, bolstering its Stored Power to incredibly dangerous levels to easily snowball if given the opportunity. Even without Terastallization, it can use its natural typing to withstand attacks from dangerous Pokemon such as Zamazenta, Great Tusk, and Mega Medicham. Hidden Power Fighting is the preferred coverage move to hit Mega Tyranitar and Heatran much harder, while Moonblast provides a stronger hit against the likes of Dragapult and Urshifu-R if Cresselia cannot afford to accumulate multiple Calm Mind boosts. Tera Poison is essential for removing Cresselia's weaknesses to Dark- and Ghost-type attacks from Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Hisuian Samurott while providing less exploitable weaknesses compared to Tera Steel, which makes Cresselia prone to being revenge killed by Fighting- and Fire-types such as Mega Lopunny, Sneasler, Heatran, and Mega Charizard Y. Covert Cloak allows Cresselia to negate secondary effects from Garganacl's Salt Cure and status from the likes of Toxapex, Sneasler, and Zapdos, while Leftovers provides passive recovery that makes Cresselia less exploitable and forced to heal. Maximum Speed EVs allow Cresselia to consistently outspeed Heatran and Gholdengo, which could otherwise irritate it, although more Defense investment could be used instead to better withstand attacks from the likes of Urshifu-R and Zamazenta. Cresselia fits best on either bulky balance or hyper offense teams, both able to provide support in different ways; the former give Cresselia a defensive core to fall back on should its sweep fail, while the latter pressure opposing defensive teams and can provide dual screens support via Tapu Koko and Dragapult to bolster its bulk even further. Both playstyles can reliably keep up Spikes using Skarmory, Clodsire, Mega Diancie, or Garchomp, which Cresselia mandates in order to wear down its checks such as Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Heatran. Similarly, Knock Off support from the likes of Toxapex and Iron Valiant helps Cresselia pressure the aforementioned checks more effectively. Cresselia has difficulty withstanding rain teams due to them cutting Moonlight's healing, so defensive partners that match up positively against them such as Toxapex and Tera Water or Dragon Garganacl are appreciated. Cresselia struggles with bulkier playstyles that can neutralize it with the likes of Haze Toxapex and Unaware Tera Dark Clodsire, so Pokemon that can break defensive teams such as Swords Dance Gliscor and Gholdengo make for good partners.

sets.name: Rain Wallbreaker
sets.description: Manaphy carves a small niche as an adequate wallbreaker on rain teams. Its Tail Glow-boosted Hydro Vortex possesses nuclear power, capable of feats like OHKOing Chansey after Stealth Rock and significantly denting Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Toxapex, and Tera Grass Heatran that give rain wallbreakers a hard time. Longevity from Rest + Hydration lets it sponge status moves in rain against defensive teams, which gives it plenty of opportunities to wallbreak by shrugging off their chip damage, such as against Toxapex and Clodsire's Toxic and Garganacl's Salt Cure. Energy Ball covers Gastrodon as well as Water-resistant foes like Rotom-W, Tera Water Ting-Lu, and Tera Water Garganacl without expending its Z-Move. Alternatively, Psychic hits Water Absorb Clodsire and Toxapex much stronger. Pelipper is a mandatory teammate due to providing the highly important rain with Drizzle. Swift Swim users like Mega Swampert and Barraskewda can keep the offensive pressure up against the opposition; their high Speed allows them to beat offensive teams by outpacing fast Pokemon like Mega Lopunny, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Koko that can overwhelm Manaphy, and they enjoy it dealing with bulky teams in return, impairing the likes of Tangrowth, Slowbro, and Rotom-W for them. Utility options from Tornadus-T and Ferrothorn are also appreciated; the former checks Kartana and Serperior that would otherwise revenge kill Manaphy, while the latter covers Tapu Koko and provides entry hazards. Kingambit and Weavile can Pursuit trap Dragapult and Mega Latias, both of which are problematic for Manaphy to face.

sets.name: Tail Glow
sets.description: Manaphy has a niche as a powerful wallbreaker outside of rain thanks to Tail Glow and its solid coverage, breaking through defensive foes such as Hippowdon, Heatran, and Garganacl. Energy Ball hits foes such as Gastrodon, Rotom-W, and Tapu Fini while Psychic hits foes such as Toxapex and Water Absorb Clodsire. Rindo Berry can be used so Manaphy can avoid revenge killers such as Kartana while improving its matchup against foes such as Tangrowth. Alternatively, Wacan Berry helps prevent Manaphy from being revenge killed by Tapu Koko and Iron Valiant. Ice Beam can be used over Psychic or Energy Ball to dent Dragonite, Ferrothorn, and Hydreigon, but Manaphy can no longer hit foes such as Toxapex and Gastrodon. Salac Berry with Substitute with either Tera Steel or Grass can be used to exploit the Pokemon that Manaphy threatens such as Hippowdon and Garganacl, outspeeding would-be revenge killers such as Tapu Koko and Kartana. Tera Water is used to boost the power of Surf, allowing Manaphy to 2HKO foes such as Ferrothorn and Unaware Clodsire. Manaphy fits best on offensive teams that appreciate its wallbreaking capabilities. Dual screens support from Tapu Koko or Grimmsnarl improves Manaphy's longevity, allowing it to set up easier. Teammates such as Dragapult and Volcarona appreciate Manaphy removing troublesome foes such as Mega Tyranitar, Kingambit, and Heatran for them to sweep. Manaphy also appreciates entry hazard support from teammates such as Glimmora and Landorus-T weakening foes such as Ferrothorn so Manaphy can break through them easier.

sets.name: Sun Sweeper
sets.description: With Chlorophyll, powerful STAB options in Solar Blade and Close Combat, along with a respectable base 105 Attack stat, Hisuian Lilligant can function as a powerful sun sweeper. It pairs well with the main sun setter, Mega Charizard Y, as it can switch into and threaten Mega Charizard Y’s checks such as Hippowdon, Heatran, and Clodsire; in return, Mega Charizard Y beats its checks like Gholdengo and Mega Scizor, if Hisuian Lilligant lacks Tera Blast. Solar Blade is used for raw power, although Leaf Blade is still an option for consistency outside sun. Tera Blast Fire, especially in sun, gives Lilligant a powerful third STAB option to punish foes that can tank its original STAB combination like Gholdengo, Mega Scizor, and Tera Poison Cresselia. Sleep Powder is an option to shut down checks such as Dragapult or scout for Tera types from Pokemon like Kingambit and Dondozo, which can be used as setup fodders or opportunities to give a free switch to an ally; this also allows Hisuian Lilligant to use Tera Fighting over Tera Fire for more power. Ice Spinner is another option, granting an OHKO on Flying-types that can absorb Hisuian Lilligant's STAB options such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and most Zapdos sets. Hazard support is invaluable in allowing boosted Solar Blade to OHKO Toxapex lacking Heavy-Duty Boots and Mega Scizor, making Great Tusk and Heatran good partners that also passively benefit from the sun. Finally, Hisuian Lilligant is vulnerable to being revenge killed by faster threats once the sun ends, so it appreciates a sturdy defensive core to back it up; Toxapex, Heatran, and Great Tusk can tank hits from and reliably check threats such as Iron Valiant and Mega Lopunny once the sun goes down, while Landorus-T and Rotom-W are examples of pivots that can help bring Hisuian Lilligant in more easily.

sets.name: Hustle Breaker
sets.description: Hustle coupled with Victory Dance can be used to break common defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, Great Tusk, Landorus, Kingambit, and Heatran; Hisuian Lilligant also outspeeds a good portion of the metagame after a Victory Dance boost, allowing it to threaten even common Choice Scarf users such as Urshifu-R, Tapu Lele, and Gholdengo. Its main drawback lies in the decrease in accuracy, which makes it inconsistent and potentially easy to KO. Wide Lens can be used to circumvent this, as the accuracy boost will minimize the chances of a miss. Grassium Z can allow Hisuian Lilligant to dismantle defensive cores, letting it OHKO the likes of Toxapex , Landorus-T, and defensive Tornadus-T and heavily damage Zapdos after a Victory Dance and Stealth Rock damage to potentially open up a hole for another ally like Kartana or Volcarona to clean up. Victory Dance allows it to outpace most of the metagame and fire off powerful attacks. Tera Blast Ground allows Hisuian Lilligant to snipe Gholdengo and Skeledirge for super effective damage whilst also notably beating common Poison-types like Toxapex and Sneasler. Sleep Powder can be considered to shut down foes and set up more easily. Ice Spinner is also an option to beat common Flying-types like Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Tera Flying Kingambit. Icium Z is an option when running this, as it allows Hisuian Lilligant to score an OHKO on Gliscor, defensive Landorus-T, and defensive Garchomp whilst avoiding Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin chip from the latter two. Hisuian Lilligant has trouble setting up, as it is frail enough to be susceptible to the multitude of offensive Pokemon in the tier. Its inconsistent accuracy may also sometimes leave it open to attacks. Thus, dual screens support from the likes of Grimmsnarl and Tapu Koko is beneficial, although it should be noted that the latter summons Electric Terrain, which nullifies Sleep Powder. Entry hazard support is important to score OHKOs on certain Pokemon; for example, Bloom Doom OHKOes Toxapex and Tornadus lacking Heavy-Duty Boots after Stealth Rock damage. As such, Garchomp and Ferrothorn are examples of good entry hazard setters. Finally, Hisuian Lilligant can still be defensively checked by Pokemon like Zapdos, if lacking Ice Spinner, Volcarona, and defensive Gholdengo; allies that can beat these checks include Volcarona and Mega Diancie.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Hisuian Zoroark plays as a terrifying setup sweeper with its Nasty Plot set, as it has an amazing STAB combination and can bait Pokemon with Illusion. It can break through Heatran, Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and Kingambit with Focus Blast, which in tandem with Tera Fighting allows Hisuian Zoroark to strengthen its Focus Blast to break the aforementioned threats more easily while also baiting Sucker Punch from Kingambit. Setup sweepers and wallbreakers like Mega Scizor and Iron Valiant appreciate Hisuian Zoroark baiting Skeledirge and Gholdengo. In return, Mega Scizor deals with Weavile and Kartana while Iron Valiant threatens Ting-Lu and Kingambit. Great Tusk is also a valuable teammate, as it deals with threats like Kingambit and Mega Lopunny while also providing general utility. While Hisuian Zoroark is powerful, it is vulernable to revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny, Dragapult, and Tapu Koko. As such, Pokemon like Zapdos, Slowbro, Ferrothorn, Kingambit and Great Tusk are good partners. Checks to revenge killers like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Dragapult are recommended; these include Mega Scizor, Gholdengo, Ting-Lu, Kingambit, and Heatran.

sets.name: Happy Hour
