Sneasler serves as an excellent late-game cleaner on hyper offense teams. Entry hazard setters such as Mega Diancie or Landorus-T are useful teammates to help wear down Snealser's checks, such as Toxapex and opposing Landorus-T, into KO range for its attacks. Given Sneasler's item, a Terrain-setting partner such as Tapu Koko or Tapu Lele is mandatory. Tapu Koko provides entry opporunities with Volt Switch and U-turn while also setting Reflect and Light Screen, which facilitates setup. Tapu Lele pressures Toxapex, and its Psychic Terrain blocks priority attacks such as Bullet Punch from Mega Scizor, Fake Out from Mega Lopunny, and Sucker Punch from Kingambit, all of which can otherwise pick off a weakened Sneasler. However, one should be aware that Psychic Terrain will no longer block priority moves against a Tera Flying Snealser that has Terastallized. Other offensive partners that synergize well with Sneasler include Kingambit, Dragonite, and Volcarona, all of which can either assist in breaking through Sneasler's checks, such as Landorus-T, Gliscor, or Toxapex, or finish off a team weakened by Sneasler.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description: Sneasler can use its combination of high Attack and Speed to function as a potent pivot, racking up chip damage against defensive Pokemon such as Landorus-T, Zapdos, Great Tusk, and other tanks. Its ability, Poison Touch, alongside Dire Claw allows it to spread status and cripple its checks, mainly to enable Hex Dragapult and hit would-be checks like Toxapex, Gastrodon, and Clefable for massive damage. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Sneasler to ignore Stealth Rock and Spikes to continue switching in and retain its offensive presence throughout the game. However, Sneasler is also hindered by contact punishment from the likes of Ferrothorn, defensive Landorus-T and Garchomp, and Zapdos, so Protective Pads helps provide more longevity. U-turn allows Sneasler to function as a pivot, bringing in other offensive threats such as Dragapult along with other special attackers like Tapu Lele to take advantage of physical tanks that can wall Sneasler such as Toxapex, Gliscor, and Landorus-T. U-turn also allows it to easily spread poison with Poison Touch. Fire Punch allows Sneasler to hit Gholdengo, which is immune to its STAB combination, and also dent Mega Scizor. Night Slash could be considered as an alternative to hit Dragapult switching in while also still hitting Gholdengo. Fake Out is another possibility to allow Sneasler to safely poison faster threats. However, Sneasler is easily checked by faster Pokemon that can threaten to revenge kill it such as offensive Tornadus-T, Choice Scarf users such as Urshifu-R or Landorus-T, and powerful priority users like Extreme Killer Dragonite. As such, Sneasler benefits from having a sturdy defensive backbone with Pokemon like Toxapex or Ferrothorn to tank hits that Sneasler dislikes. Sneasler also forces a lot of switches, so it benefits from allies that can set hazards like Ferrothorn, Skarmory, or Heatran, which also switch in on Flying- and Psychic-type moves for Sneasler. Sneasler also has a tendency to be completely walled by the likes of Toxapex, Gliscor, and Landorus-T and benefits greatly from having allies that it can pivot to in order to exploit these checks for damage, like Tapu Lele or Zapdos.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Enamorus is a potent wallbreaker, utilizing its strong Moonblast alongside colorful coverage to punch severe holes into defensive cores. Earth Power and Mystical Fire complement its STAB Moonblast well, with the former hitting Toxapex, Clodsire, Gholdengo, and Heatran, while the latter OHKOes Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor. Focus Blast grants Enamorus its strongest attack to hit Garganacl and Mega Tyranitar, which could otherwise survive Earth Power and Moonblast, respectively, while Psychic provides a safer middle ground option for Toxapex Clodsire, and Mega Venusaur, which staves off its attacks otherwise. Tera Fairy grants Enamorus a power boost to Moonblast, notably allowing it to secure OHKOs against the likes of Landorus-T and Rotom-W, which would barely survive it otherwise. Enamorus fits best on bulky offense teams that appreciate its wallbreaking power while being able to support it adequately. Pivots such as Mega Lopunny, Landorus-T, and Tornadus-T grant Enamorus free switch in opportunities against Great Tusk, opposing Landorus-T, and Rotom-W. The latter two pivots and Great Tusk, also provide entry hazard removal, which aids Enamorus given its Stealth Rock weakness. Enamorus works well with fast cleaners such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Choice Scarf Kartana, as they appreciate Enamorus punching holes into the likes of Gholdengo and Mega Scizor for the latter two to clean up weakened defensive cores.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description: Calm Mind Enamorus serve as a solid wallbreaker, using forced switches from the likes of Great Tusk and Garchomp to set up. It is incredibly difficult to switch into after a boost given its strong Moonblast alongside coverage options in Earth Power and Mystical Fire to hit Fairy-resistant foes such as Heatran, Toxapex, and Ferrothorn, respectively. Alternatively, Enamorus can forgo Mystical Fire for Substitute to take advantage of pivoting attempts as well as sponge attacks from revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny and Iron Valiant, although it makes it less effective at hitting Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor. If using Substitute, Enamorus can opt for Leftovers instead of the standard Heavy-Duty Boots to potentially set up more Substitutes. Tera Ground boosts the power of Earth Power, allowing it to KO most Toxapex and Gholdengo sets after a boost, as well as giving it an immunity to Tapu Koko and Rotom-W's Electric-type attacks. Enamorus fits best on bulky offense and offense teams that appreciate its use as an early- to mid-game wallbreaker while granting it sufficient opportunities to enter the field. Therefore, pivots such as Mega Lopunny and Landorus-T pair well with it, bringing Enamorus in on physical walls it can exploit such as Great Tusk, Buzzwole, and Skarmory. Additionally, Pursuit trappers such as Mega Tyranitar and Weavile eliminate special walls such as Clodsire and Gholdengo that can serve as a roadblock to Enamorus. Fast late-game cleaners such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Choice Scarf Kartana appreciate Enamorus, as they capitalize on it weakening or removing Steel-types for them to clean up.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf Enamorus functions as an interesting revenge killer, being able to KO a range of setup sweepers such as Dragonite, Mega Gyarados, Baxcalibur, and even a weakened Volcarona courtesy of its great speed tier. Additionally, it can serve as a late-game cleaner once its checks such as Toxapex, Gholdengo, and Assault Vest Tornadus-T have been weakened by its teammates. However, its Stealth Rock weakness and relative frailty mean Enamorus struggles to withstand repeated switches as well as priority moves from the likes of Urshifu-R and Mega Lopunny. Tera Fairy boosts the power of Moonblast, notably allowing it to 2HKO Assault Vest Tornadus-T after Stealth Rock. Aside from coverage to hit Steel-types in Mystical Fire and Earth Power, Healing Wish can bring back a weakened teammate in a pinch, potentially being able to change the tide of a game. Therefore, Enamorus fits best on offense teams that appreciate its utility in Healing Wish while providing a positive matchup against opposing offensive teams. Powerful wallbreakers such as Baxcalibur and Volcarona appreciate Enamorus's Healing Wish, giving them a second lease on life, while Enamorus in turn capitalizes on them weakening the likes of Toxapex and Mega Scizor to clean late-game. Enamorus also greatly enjoys entry hazard removal support from Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, or Great Tusk, as it minimalizes its Stealth Rock weakness so it can switch in more effectively mid-game. Enamorus struggles with special wall such as Clodsire and Gholdengo, so Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk make for good partners that can take advantage of them.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: When it comes to Unaware Pokemon, Skeledirge is one of the best available; it has great physical bulk and a solid move in Torch Song, which boosts its already good Special Attack. These traits make it a hard-to-break physical wall and a potential wincon as well. Will-O-Wisp lets it cripple physical attackers such as Mega Tyranitar, Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T while also punishing Water-types such as Rotom-W. Combined with Will-O-Wisp, Hex helps it overwhelm passive checks in Toxapex, Gastrodon, and Clodsire while also allowing Skeledirge to sweep statused teams. While not as strong as Hex, Shadow Ball is a decent option as it's more consistent. Tera Water allows Skeledirge to beat rain teams by spreading burns against rain sweepers such as Mega Swampert, Barraskewda, and Floatzel. On the other hand, Tera Fairy allows it to counter Dragon Dance Dragapult and avoid Pursuit from Kingambit, Mega Tyranitar, and Weavile while also keeping a Fighting resistance, meaning it can still check Zamazenta. It also removes Skeledirge's Ground weakness, allowing it to comfortably burn Pokemon like Garchomp, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T. Skeledirge struggles against Heatran and Garganacl, as it can't burn them nor deal significant damage to them. Therefore, Pokemon that pressure them like Garchomp and Rotom-W for the former and Cover Cloak Gholdengo for the latter make good partners. Skeledirge also hates losing its item, so Knock Off absorbers like Flyinium Z Tornadus-T and Gliscor make for good teammates. The former can also weaken Heatran for it while Skeledirge can burn Mega Tyranitar. Special sponges like Gastrodon, Clodsire, and Toxapex all appreciate Skeledirge's ability to cripple physical attackers such as Kartana, Mega Lopunny, and Kingambit, alleviating the pressure these Pokemon exert on them. In return, they can all handle special attackers like Gholdengo, Choice Specs Dragapult, and Mega Charizard Y.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: IronPress
sets.description: Garganacl is an astounding wincon due to the combination of Iron Defense + Body Press allowing it to beat Pokemon like Dragonite, Kingambit, and Great Tusk. Salt Cure makes easy progress and accrues chip damage on switch-ins like Gholdengo, Rotom-W, Heatran, and Great Tusk while also forcing Pokemon like Gastrodon and Mega Scizor to burn their recovery PP more often, making them passive and more easily worn down. Recover allows Garganacl to check Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Dragapult long-term and increasess its sustainability as a wincon. Tera Water allows Garganacl to check Pokemon like Gholdengo and Urshifu-R while providing valuable resistances to Steel- and Water-type moves. Notably, It allows Garganacl to stave off rain attackers such as Mega Swampert and Barraskewda. Alternatively, Tera Fairy lets Garganacl reliably set up in front of Pokemon like Great Tusk and Zamazenta while also being a near hard check to Dragapult. Maximum Special Defense investment allows Garganacl to deal with Pokemon like Tapu Koko and Choice Specs Dragapult reliably. Pokemon like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Gholdengo pair well with Garganacl as they serve as reliable defensive checks to strong wallbreakers like Urshifu-R, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Lele, respectively. Entry hazard removers like Tornadus-T and Great Tusk are also appreciated, as Garganacl is susceptible to chip damage from entry hazard. Garganacl mandates Knock Off support to serve as an effective wincon, as it can be pivoted around with Regenerator Pokemon holding Heavy-Duty Boots such as Toxapex and Slowbro without it. As such, partners such as the aforementioned Tornadus-T and Kingambit are useful. It additionally needs entry hazard support from Pokemon such as Clodsire and Heatran to outdamage Regenerator. Wallbreakers like Iron Valiant and Kartana appreciate their checks in Skeledirge and Gholdengo from being worn down by Salt Cure; these Pokemon also appreciate having Garganacl as a wall to fall back on. Pokemon that can support Garganacl to let it clean up late-game like Weavile, Tapu Lele, and Kingambit pair well with it, as they can immediately remove Pokemon that Garganacl would struggle with, such as Covert Cloak Gholdengo and Urshifu-R.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description: Garganacl is a great entry hazard setter, as it takes advantage of the myriad of switches it forces with Salt Cure and ability to exploit passive Pokemon such as Toxapex and Clodsire. Salt Cure aggressively accumulates chip damage on switch-ins such as Urshifu-R and Kartana, and it punishes entry hazard removers like Great Tusk, Rotom-W, and Tornadus-T. Protect allows Garganacl to accrue more recovery from Leftovers and scout Pokemon like Great Tusk, Iron Valiant, and Dragapult, all while accruing chip damage on them with Salt Cure. Recover maintains Garganacl's longevity against Pokemon like Dragapult and Tapu Koko. Tera Water gives it neat resistances to Gholdengo's Make It Rain and Urshifu-R's Surging Strikes while also improving its matchup against rain wallbreakers such as Mega Swampert and Floatzel. Tera Fairy lets it handle Pokemon like Tera Grass Volcarona and Zamazenta safely, and it renders Dragapult useless against it. Maximum Special Defense investment allows Garganacl to deal with Pokemon like Volcarona, Tornadus-T, and Tapu Lele reliably. Pokemon like Toxapex, Kingambit, and Gholdengo support Garganacl as they deal with strong wallbreakers like Urshifu-R, Gholdengo, and Tapu Lele; Gholdengo in particular makes an amazing teammate as it prevents Defog and Rapid Spin from clearing Garganacl's Stealth Rock while also dealing with Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Kartana. Garganacl appreciates Knock Off users such as Tornadus-T and Toxapex, as they let it beat Regenerator Pokemon such as Slowbro and Toxapex with its own entry hazards. Pokemon that like their defensive checks being worn down due to Stealth Rock and Salt Cure such as Tapu Lele and Mega Medicham appreciate Garganacl's presence, as it wears down Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Gholdengo.

sets.name: Stored Power
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description: Glimmora is a valuable dedicated lead on hyper offense teams that can reliably set up multiple entry hazards in Stealth Rock, Toxic Spikes, and potentially Spikes, as well as remove opposing ones with Mortal Spin. It can make use of its solid coverage options and remarkable Special Attack to pose a noticeable offensive threat itself, especially against common entry hazard setters, removers, and other dedicated leads. Power Gem threatens the metagame's best Defogger in Tornadus-T, while Sludge Bomb dents screens setters such as Grimmsnarl and Tapu Koko and—if Focus Sash is still intact—Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant as well, which can be problematic against offensive teams. Earth Power pressures Steel-types like Heatran, Gholdengo, and Kingambit that would otherwise block Glimmora's Mortal Spin, while Energy Ball deals with other entry hazard setters and removers such as Great Tusk, Gastrodon, Mega Swampert, and Rotom-W. Focus Sash guarantees that Glimmora can set at least one layer of entry hazards, potentially letting Toxic Debris trigger twice as well. Tera Ghost is used in a pinch to spinblock foes such as Great Tusk and Excadrill and remove its Ground weakness to set up multiple entry hazards in the face of other setters like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Gastrodon. Gholdengo is a near-mandatory teammate to keep up entry hazards by blocking every attempts to remove them, such as Defog and Rapid Spin. Setup sweepers like Kingambit, Volcarona, Dragapult, Dragonite, and Iron Valiant appreciate entry hazards wearing down foes such as Dondozo and Clodsire and not being chipped down by opposing ones themselves; particularly, Kingambit's Knock Off can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from the likes of Tornadus-T, Toxapex, and Volcarona to make them vulnerable to Glimmora's entry hazards.

sets.name: Curse
sets.description: Thanks to its massive physical bulk and ability, Unaware, Dondozo serves as a wall for physical setup sweepers, such as Dragonite, Kingambit, and Dragon Dance Dragapult. Dondozo also annoys rain teams, shutting down wallbreakers such as Floatzel, Barraskewda, and Mega Swampert. With Curse, Dondozo can also function as a late-game sweeper. Liquidation is preferred to Wave Crash given that it has more PP and does not incur recoil. However, Wave Crash can also be considered for its greater power. Leftovers is preferred to maximize longevity; however, Heavy-Duty Boots is worth consideration to fortify switches into entry hazards. Tera Grass transforms Dondozo's Electric and Grass weaknesses into resistances, turning common threats in Tapu Koko and Kartana into fodder and avoiding Leech Seed from Ferrothorn. Dondozo fits best on bulky offense and balance teams, as they greatly appreciate its ability to wall physical setup sweepers. Given its mediocre special bulk, special walls such as Clodsire and Ting-Lu make for good teammates, as they can switch into special attackers such as Tapu Koko, Tera Grass Volcarona, and Choice Specs Dragapult. Gholdengo is another good teammate since it checks dangerous special wallbreakers such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant that can play around Dondozo's commonly paired special walls. Other Pokemon that can beat these threats include Mega Scizor and Clodsire.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description: Clodsire serves as a fantastic special wall, able to take on powerful attackers such as Dragapult and Mega Diancie while simultaneously stopping setup sweepers such as Gholdengo and Volcarona. Spikes are preferred on Clodsire, as the move has more limited distribution and Clodsire enters the field commonly enough to have the opportunity to use the move. However, Stealth Rock can be used if Clodsire's team requires it. Toxic is used to cripple common switch-ins to Clodsire, such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Great Tusk. Poison Jab can be used to poison post-Tera Gholdengo attempting to remove its Ground weakness, and it forces damage on Tornadus-T faster. Heavy-Duty Boots are preferred on Clodsire to negate its weakness to opposing Spikes teams, although Leftovers are also viable to increase Clodsire's longevity. Unaware is preferred over Water Absorb to negate Clodsire's passivity against setup sweepers, and Water Absorb does little to help against the likes of Mega Swampert and Gastrodon. Tera Dark grants Clodsire a Ghost resistance, which helps against Choice Specs Dragapult and Gholdengo, especially if using Poison Jab against the latter. It also grants Clodsire with a Pursuit resistance against the likes of Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar, which can both exploit its physical frailty. Clodsire fits best on defensively oriented teams that appreciate its special walling and entry hazard support. As Clodsire is weak to most physical attackers such as Kingambit, Great Tusk, and Dragonite, teammates that can cover them, such as Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Buzzwole, make for good partners. In return, Clodsire can switch into Electric-type attacks for the former, and powerful special attackers such as Dragapult for the latter two. Pokemon that benefit from Spikes support, such as Tornadus-T and Gholdengo, also pair well with Clodsire, as Spikes puts pressure on checks to them such as Ting-Lu and Mega Tyranitar. In return, Clodsire appreciates these teammates being able to make more immediate progress. Knock Off users such as the aforementioned Tornadus-T as well as Weavile and Mega Scizor pair well with Clodsire, crippling Heavy-Duty Boots users such as opposing Clodsire and Toxapex, giving Clodsire's entry hazards support a greater impact.

sets.name: Offensive Utility
sets.description: Great Tusk is an excellent Pokemon due to its amazing physical bulk, defensive typing, role compression, and movepool. It also has a very strong offensive presence and has utility moves in Rapid Spin and Stealth Rock to back it up. Headlong Rush is an amazing STAB move, letting Great Tusk force out Pokemon such as Heatran, Gholdengo, and Skeledirge very well. Earthquake can be used for a no-drawback STAB move, but the lack in power is certainly noticeable. Close Combat allows Great Tusk to annihilate Pokemon like Kingambit, and Ferrothorn, and it does a nice chunk to Rotom-W on the switch. Rapid Spin provides reliable entry hazard control, which is especially useful because Great Tusk forces out common Stealth Rock users like Heatran and Mega Tyranitar. It also lets Great Tusk outspeed foes like Iron Valiant, non-Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, and Tornadus-T. Ice Spinner lets Great Tusk hit Landorus-T, Dragonite, and Tornadus-T for good damage. Heavy-Duty Boots gives Great Tusk an entry hazard immunity and allows it to safely Rapid Spin, while Leftovers gives it passive recovery and lets it reliably check Pokemon like Kingambit and Garchomp. Icium Z allows Great Tusk to immediately remove Pokemon like Garchomp and Tornadus while also taking advantage of Tera Grass Heatran. Booster Energy can be used to improve Great Tusk's already great offensive output, but since it is a one-time use item, it can be quite unreliable. Tera Water improves the matchup into Pokemon like Urshifu-R and Floatzel. Tera Ground removes Great Tusk's Fairy and Psychic weakness and bolsters its offensive output, letting it OHKO Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, and Volcarona. Tera Steel gives Great Tusk resistances to the majority of its weaknesses, letting it KO Pokemon such as Tornadus-T, Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Tapu Koko after luring them. Gholdengo and Kingambit make excellent partners for Great Tusk, as Gholdengo safely handles Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant while Kingambit can force out and Pursuit Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Dragapult. Great Tusk is commonly used as setup fodder against Pokemon like Iron Valiant and Volcarona, so partners like Clodsire and Dragonite can support it in that case. Entry hazard setters like Ferrothorn appreciate Rapid Spin support from Great Tusk, as it lets them keep entry hazards up while removing opposing ones, preventing the team from being worn down quickly. Stealth Rock-weak wallbreakers like Nasty Plot Tornadus-T and Mega Charizard Y also appreciate entry hazard removal from Great Tusk, as it lets them come in multiple times and poke holes in the opposition.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: 96 Speed EVs let it outspeed non-Choice Scarf Kartana at +1 Speed.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: A blend of a great Speed stat and solid mixed bulk, combined with great utility options and an interesting defensive typing, Scream Tail a solid niche in the tier, allowing it to check dangerous threats such as Mega Diancie, Tapu Lele, and Mega Medicham. Wish and Protect provide Scream Tail with recovery, with the latter also scouting Choice-locked Pokemon such as Dragapult and Kartana. Dazzling Gleam punishes Great Tusk and Iron Valiant and prevents them from freely exploiting Scream Tail. Encore pairs excellently with Scream Tail's high Speed, allowing it to shut down setup sweepers such as Urshifu-R, Cresselia, and Garchomp for its teammates to defeat. Leftovers provides Scream Tail with recovery that makes it less susceptible to being exploited by Wish, granting Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Heatran free switches. The given EVs maximize Scream Tail's bulk while allowing it to outspeed Enamorus and shut down Calm Mind variants with Encore. An alternative spread of 120 HP / 236 SpD / 152 Spe can be used to outspeed Hydreigon while receiving a Special Defense boost in Mega Charizard Y's sun, further amplifying Scream Tail's bulk and allowing it to check Charizard under sun. Tera Steel grants a resistance to Ice- and Fairy-type attacks from Kyurem, Tapu Lele, and Iron Valiant in a pinch, while Tera Fairy ensures Scream Tail resists Pursuit from Weavile and Mega Tyranitar and increases the power of Dazzling Gleam to potentially 2HKO and OHKO Garchomp and Iron Valiant, respectively. Scream Tail fits best on defensively oriented teams that appreciate its unique defensive attributes while being able to support it sufficiently in return. Pokemon with unreliable recovery such as Great Tusk, Dondozo, and Assault Vest Toxapex appreciate Scream Tail's high-HP Wishes, while in return they check Pokemon Scream Tail struggles with such as Mega Scizor and Volcarona. Due to its reliance on Protect and Leftovers for passive recovery, entry hazard control from teammates such as the aforementioned Great Tusk and Tornadus-T can help mitigate its recovery. Scream Tail's passive nature means it can be exploited by Steel-types such as Gholdengo, Ferrothorn, and Heatran, so Pokemon that aid against them while providing a more dangerous presence such as Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Swords Dance Gliscor pair well with it.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: STAB U-turn and First Impression combined with a massive Attack stat make Slither Wing a solid wallbreaker, revenge killer, and pivot. First Impression clears Pokemon such as Kartana while also denting Bug-resistant Pokemon such as Dragapult and Mega Lopunny. U-turn lets Slither Wing obtain momentum while also chipping switch-ins like Tornadus-T and Landorus-T. Flare Blitz tears through Gholdengo and is Slither Wing's strongest attack against Landorus-T and Gliscor, while Earthquake hits Pokemon like Toxapex and Skeledirge while still threatening Gholdengo as well. Tera Bug bolsters First Impression's power to high levels, maximizing Slither Wing's revenge killing potential and enabling it to spread much more chip damage with U-turn; however, it gains a Stealth Rock weakness. Slither Wing pairs well with Mega Charizard Y, as it enables Protosynthesis, which lets Slither Wing threaten the opposition more often. It also boosts Flare Blitz, letting it dent Landorus-T and Gliscor better. In return, Mega Charizard Y threatens Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Gholdengo. Special wallbreakers that wear down Slither Wing checks such as Mega Diancie and Tapu Koko pair well with it; they also benefit from Slither Wing breaking their checks. Slither Wing lures in Flying-types such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Dragonite, so Pokemon such as Weavile and Tapu Koko pair well with it, both notably forcing Dragonite to Terastallize into the Normal-type and making it prone to First Impression.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: Sandy Shocks is a niche pivot thanks to its ability to switch into threats like Tornadus-T and Tapu Koko. Tera Blast with Tera Ice allows Sandy Shocks to blast through Ground- and Flying-types that are immune to its STAB moves like Garchomp, Dragonite, and most notably, Landorus-T. Alternatively, Tera Grass with Tera Blast is another option to hit Mega Swampert and Gastrodon super effectively and gives it a resistance to Ground, although it becomes completely ruined by Gliscor. If not using Tera Blast, Stealth Rock and Spikes allow Sandy Shocks to support its teammates by wearing down threats like Skeledirge, Gholdengo, and Tornadus-T. Tera Ground allows Sandy Shocks to boost the power of Earth Power, take less entry hazard damage, and shed its Ground weakness. Pokemon that appreciate being safely brought in like Heatran, Dragapult, and Annihilape against threats to it such as Ferrothorn, Dragonite, and Weavile are great partners for Sandy Shocks. Knock Off support from Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Great Tusk allows Sandy Shocks to capitalize on chipping down switch-ins like Dragonite and Tornadus-T. Sandy Shocks struggles against Ground-types without Tera Blast or if another teammate Terastallizes, therefore, Pokemon that threaten them such as Kartana, Walking Wake, and Weavile are great teammates.

sets.name: Entry Hazard Lead
sets.description: Iron Treads has a niche as an interesting entry hazard lead in the metagame. With both Stealth Rock and Rapid Spin, it can lay entry hazards while keeping them off for its teammates, and it is very threatening to Magic Bounce Pokemon in Mega Diancie and Hatterene. Steel Beam allows Iron Treads to sacrifice itself quickly in order to deny Defog attempts from the likes of Tornadus-T, Landorus-T, and Rotom-W. It is also Iron Treads's main tool of pressuring Hatterene, and it is generally powerful enough to chunk certain Ground-resistant and immune Pokemon, like Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Buzzwole. Booster Energy and Quark Drive together allows Iron Treads to outrun the entire unboosted metagame as well as Choice Scarf users like Tapu Lele, Urshifu-R, and Gholdengo, allowing it to consistently lay entry hazards. Tera Ghost allows Iron Treads to block opposing Rapid Spin attempts from Great Tusk if necessary. Iron Treads should be used as a lead on hyper offense teams, so other support teammates and sweepers are natural partners. Dual screens setters like Grimmsnarl and Tapu Koko allow their sweeping teammates another layer of support and safety, and they can use Taunt to consistently deny Defog attempts even after Iron Treads has fainted. Common hyper offense sweepers, like Mega Gyarados, Galarian Moltres, Kingambit, Volcarona, and Baxcalibur appreciate Iron Treads laying Stealth Rock while keeping hazards off at the same time. The former two in particular appreciate this, as Mega Gyarados is weak to Stealth Rock before mega evolving, while Galarian Moltres often prefers other items over Heavy-Duty Boots.

sets.name: Bulky Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance Iron Hands is a potent wincon, using its amazing bulk in conjunction with its perfect coverage to punch holes in faster teams that lack the means to consistently wall it and trade extremely well. Wild Charge and Close Combat are higher power options over Thunder Punch and Drain Punch that allow for a few notable benchmarks, such as having a chance to 2HKO Tera Water Skeledirge and OHKOing defensive Rotom-W after Stealth Rock and a Swords Dance, but they both greatly sacrifice longevity. Ice Punch lets it nail Ground-, Flying- and Dragon-types that resist its STAB combination such as Landorus-T, Dragonite, Zapdos, and Great Tusk. Tera Water lets Iron Hands gain a much stronger defensive type overall, preventing Ground-, Psychic-, and Fairy-types from revenge killing it while improving the rain matchup significantly. The given EV spread allows Iron Hands to KO Tapu Lele with Thunder Punch after a Swords Dance and outspeed Chansey, with the rest dumped into Special Defense to maximize its lower special bulk. Entry hazard support from Garchomp, Gastrodon, Ferrothorn, and Mega Diancie is crucial to Iron Hands, as it quickly wears down all of its checks for it to clean late-game. Future Sight support is also notable, as it allows Iron Hands to bypass would-be checks such as Buzzwole and Skeledirge. Pivots such as Tapu Koko, Tornadus-T, and Landorus-T also work well with Iron Hands, as they bring it in safely and prevent it from being worn down quickly. Tapu Koko's Electric Terrain also activates Iron Hands's Quark Drive, boosting its Attack even further. Due to its great defensive utility, it partners well with Pokemon like Slowbro and Dragapult, as it takes advantage of Dark-types that pressure these two out, with Slowbro providing Future Sight support and Dragapult taking advantage of Iron Hands’s checks like Buzzwole and Skeledirge. Due to its lack of longevity, it is a poor singular check to threats such as Kingambit, Weavile, and Kartana, so pairing it up with Pokemon like tank Garchomp, Tapu Fini, and Rotom-W to form defensive a defensive core works wonders.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Iron Jugulis serves as a solid wallbreaker, utilizing its solid STAB combination, coverage, and Speed tier to threaten foes. Earth Power snipes would-be checks like Heatran, Toxapex, and Mega Diancie. U-turn lets Iron Jugulis pivot into Pokemon that solve unfavorable matchups for it such as Kartana and Mega Scizor while also providing momentum for teammates like Tapu Koko and Great Tusk. Tera Flying boosts Hurricane to obscene levels while also giving it a resistance to Close Combat from the likes of Mega Lopunny and Zamazenta. Alternatively, Tera Ground gives Iron Jugulis a Stealth Rock resistance and gives it an easier time breaking through the likes of Mega Tyranitar and Clodsire. Iron Jugulis values pivots like Tapu Koko, Landorus-T, and Slowbro, as they provide it opportunities for it to come in and pressure Pokemon like Tangrowth and opposing Slowbro. Tapu Koko in particular is an astounding partner, as it enables Quark Drive for Iron Jugulis, which lets it outspeed Pokemon like Dragapult and Mega Lopunny. Slowbro also provides Future Sight to pressure Toxapex and Clodsire. Pokemon that can wear down checks to Iron Jugulis such as Assault Vest Tornadus-T and Ting-Lu with entry hazards like Landorus-T, Ferrothorn, and Heatran are appreciated. Entry hazard removers such as the aforementioned Tornadus-T and Rotom-W help compensate for Iron Jugulis's Stealth Rock weakness.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Iron Moth's power, Speed tier, and U-turn allow it to function well as an offensive pivot. Energy Ball hits Gastrodon and Garganacl while U-turn allows Iron Moth to pivot out of bad matchups, such as Heatran, Toxapex, and Skeledirge. Alternatively, Psychic hits Toxapex, but it makes Iron Moth a significant momentum sink against Heatran and Mega Tyranitar. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Iron Moth to act as a pivot consistently without having to worry about entry hazard chip, which it is otherwise very vulnerable to. Tera Grass surprises Mega Swampert, Mega Tyranitar, Hippowdon, and Garchomp defensively before hitting them back with a powerful Energy Ball. Iron Moth fits well on VoltTurn offenses, specifically those including Tapu Koko, who is a natural partner for it. Tapu Koko can set Electric Terrain for Iron Moth in order to boost its Special Attack and benefits from Iron Moth bringing it in on Toxapex. Conversely, Tapu Koko can bring Iron Moth in on threats to it, such as Ferrothorn and Rillaboom. Iron Moth also benefits heavily from Future Sight support, as it prevents Toxapex from safely switching in while also applying some chip onto Heatran. Slowbro can pivot into threats to Iron Moth, such as Garchomp, Mega Lopunny, and Zamazenta, while Slowking helps out even more against Heatran. Entry hazard setters like Ferrothorn, Mega Diancie, Garchomp, and Landorus-T wear down Iron Moth's checks like Heatran, Garchomp, and Mega Tyranitar. Garchomp in particular pivots into Heatran relatively well. Powerful offensive threats like Dragapult, Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Tapu Lele appreciate Iron Moth bringing them in safely on threats like Heatran, Toxapex, and Skeledirge while also being a decent wallbreaker in its own right. The former three can also use their good Speed tier to help out Iron Moth against more offensive builds.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Iron Moth is a prediction-reliant but extremely dangerous wallbreaker that can systematically break down defensive cores while still being useful against offense due to its decent Speed tier. Energy Ball hits threats such as Gastrodon, Garganacl, and Garchomp. Psychic hits Toxapex and Clodsire hard, while also having a decent chance of 2HKOing physically defensive Skeledirge. Iron Moth can also opt for Tera Blast + Tera Ground to hit Toxapex, Heatran, Skeledirge, and Clodsire all at once while removing its irritating Stealth Rock weakness. This makes Iron Moth very reliant on Terastallizing to break certain teams, however. Tera Grass should be used otherwise, as it still lessens Iron Moth's Stealth Rock weakness while also allowing it to potentially turn the tables on Garchomp, Mega Swampert, and Urshifu-R. U-turn can also be used to ease prediction and safely bring in teammates, but Iron Moth's Stealth Rock weakness makes this a risky proposition. Iron Moth needs very solid entry hazard control, so options such as Tornadus-T, Landorus-T, Cyclizar, and Great Tusk make for solid teammates; the former three can also bring Iron Moth in safely via pivoting. Tapu Koko is another great option, as Electric Terrain jacks up Iron Moth's power to titanic levels, cleanly 2HKOing Clodsire, Garchomp, and Skeledirge with Fire Blast after the Quark Drive boost. It also allows Iron Moth to deal sizable damage to physically defensive Toxapex with Fire Blast, potentially 2HKOing it after some chip. Heatran switch-ins such as Garchomp, Rotom-W, and Slowking are appreciated, as its presence makes it very hard for Iron Moth to safely use its STAB moves. The latter two can use pivot moves to bring Iron Moth in. Heatran can beat these with Tera Grass and Tera Blast, but Iron Moth will be able to use Sludge Wave on it if Terastallization is forced. Powerful anti-offense Pokemon such as Mega Lopunny, Dragapult, and Iron Valiant are good teammates, as they appreciate Iron Moth wearing down defensive cores while supporting Iron Moth against fast offenses that exploit its Speed tier.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Baxcalibur serves as a potent Dragon Dance sweeper with powerful STAB moves, threatening to OHKO the majority of the metagame at +1. Icicle Crash with Heavy-Duty Boots to flinch through potential checks such as Skarmory and Corviknight is a good alternative. Earthquake hits Steel-types such as Heatran, Kingambit, and Gholdengo, while also hitting defensive staples such as Skeledirge, Garganacl, and Toxapex. Thermal Exchange lets Baxcalibur avoid Will-O-Wisp from Pokemon like Rotom-W and Skeledirge, and it dissuades the use of moves such as Volcarona's Flamethrower and Heatran's Magma Storm, as well as coverage from Choice-locked Pokemon like Dragapult. Tera Steel lets Baxcalibur avoid Toxic while also denying Choice Scarf Tapu Lele from revenge killing it and allowing setup in front of Choice Specs Dragapult. Tera Dragon powers up Baxcalibur's Glaive Rush to lethal levels, while Earthquake boosted by Tera Ground lets Baxcalibur OHKO the aforementioned Kingambit, Garganacl, and more often that not Toxapex at +1, avoiding Iron Head, Salt Cure, and Haze, respectively. Baxcalibur functions well on offensive teams that provide dual screens support, letting it set up freely in front of Pokemon like Rotom-W and Slowbro. Baxcalibur's ability to rip holes in Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Toxapex-reliant cores greatly benefits teammates like Tapu Lele, Weavile, and Urshifu-R, which can quickly snowball late-game. Baxcalibur also appreciates Steel-types like the aforementioned Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Gholdengo, as they check Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Gholdengo in particular checks Iron Valiant, which revenge kills Baxcalibur with Quark Drive. Landorus-T pivots out on Pokemon such as Rotom-W, giving Baxcalibur an opportunity to setup while also checking threatening Fighting-types like Zamazenta and Mega Lopunny. Baxcalibur appreciates entry hazard removal for Loaded Dice sets to maximize its solid natural bulk, so teammates such as Great Tusk, Tornadus-T, and Rotom-W are appreciated. Skarmory, Mega Scizor, and Ferrothorn are particularly annoying for Baxcalibur, so teammates such as Mega Lopunny, Great Tusk, and Tapu Lele who assist in chipping them down are appreciated.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band Baxcalibur finds a niche as an adequate wallbreaker by utilizing its high Attack and a strong, spammable STAB move in Glaive Rush, 2HKOing physically bulky Pokemon like Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Slowbro. Its natural bulk alongside Thermal Exchange grants it plenty of wallbreaking opportunities, with the latter letting it ignore Rotom-W’s and the aforementioned walls' crippling Will-O-Wisp and Scald burns. Ice Shard allows it to revenge kill faster threats like Dragapult, Iron Valiant, Mega Lopunny, and Choice Scarf Landorus-T. Earthquake deals with Steel-types such as Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Heatran, and it's Baxcalibur's hardest-hitting attack against Skeledirge, Garganacl, and Mega Tyranitar. Tera Ice and Tera Dragon boost its offensive presence; the former allows Icicle Crash to 2HKO Ferrothorn and provides significant odds for Ice Shard to OHKO Tornadus-T, as well as Dragonite through Multiscale, while the latter does so similarly with Glaive Rush, possibly OHKOing Rotom-W and 2HKOing Buzzwole. A defensive alternative is viable, as Tera Steel lets Baxcalibur stomach Dragapult's Draco Meteor, Iron Valiant's Moonblast, and Gholdengo's Make it Rain, shed its Stealth Rock weakness, and switch into Toxapex's Toxic. Pivots like Tornadus-T, Rotom-W, Tapu Koko, and Landorus-T can bring Baxcalibur in safely on Pokemon like Rotom-W, Tangrowth, Clodsire, and opposing Landorus-T, respectively. Setup sweepers or late-game cleaners such as Volcarona and Iron Valiant appreciate Baxcalibur handling Toxapex, Heatran, and Clodsire, while the likes of Dragonite and Choice Scarf Kartana enjoy Baxcalibur overwhelming physical walls like Ferrothorn, Tangrowth, and Skeledirge.

sets.name: Defensive Nasty Plot
sets.description: Gholdengo uses its great typing and decent bulk to switch into Pokemon such as Tapu Lele, Hawlucha, most Mega Medicham, most Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta. Gholdengo's typing and unique ability in Good as Gold make it the premier stopgap to entry hazard removal and a good asset for entry hazard-stacking teams. Gholdengo can switch in on Defoggers like Rotom-W and Tornadus-T—the tier's top Defogger—and can switch in on status moves like Leech Seed from Ferrothorn and Toxic from Clodsire after Gholdengo Terastallizes. A STAB combination of Ghost / Steel hits many targets neutrally, with Shadow Ball being incredibly spammable and Make It Rain hitting Ghost-resistant Pokemon like Garganacl, Tyranitar, and Weavile; the former two are otherwise able to switch in freely. Tera Ghost allows Gholdengo to maintain its spinblocking abilities while strengthening Shadow Ball against foes like Toxapex and improving its matchup into Garganacl. Tera Fairy lets Gholdengo switch out of otherwise crippling Pursuit. Tera Water lets it stay in on four attacks Kingambit and begin setting up, but still leaves it vulnerable to Garganacl and taken advatange of by Rotom-W. The removal of a Ground weakness also allows it to take advantage of Heatran, Ting-Lu, and Clodsire. 128 Special Defense EVs let Gholdengo survive two Heat Waves from offensive Tornadus-T from maximum HP, while the Special Attack allows it to OHKO bulky Tornadus-T with Make It Rain after a Nasty Plot; the remaining are put in Defense to take hits from the likes of Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar much better after Terastallizing. Entry hazard setters like Ting-Lu, Clodsire, Gastrodon, and Mega Diancie appreciate their hazards staying up for as long as possible. Pokemon like Mega Lopunny appreciate Gholdengo beating common revenge killers in Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Zamazenta. Rotom-W is notable in that it checks Pokemon like Mega Swampert, Heatran, and Victini, and it appreciates Gholdengo providing entry hazard control. Gholdengo struggles against Kingambit, which it lets in for free and struggles to switch out of due to Pursuit. Kingambit is punished by Fighting-type teammates such as Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, Iron Valiant, and Mega Lopunny. Gholdengo also struggles against Mega Lopunny, which can switch in on stray Shadow Balls and bypass its Fighting immunity with Scrappy. Gholdengo also struggles against Clodsire and opposing Ghost-types, such as Dragapult and opposing Gholdengo. These can be checked by Pursuit users such as Weavile, Kingambit, and Mega Tyranitar.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Ting-Lu is an outstanding wall, utilizing its immense bulk, Vessel of Ruin, and useful defensive typing to check threats such as Dragapult, Espathra, and Tapu Koko well. With access to both Stealth Rock and Spikes, Ting-Lu is a flexible entry hazard setter that supports its teammates well. Ruination allows Ting-Lu to pressure Pokemon such as Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T, which don't care about its Earthquake. Rest is an option for more longevity across the length of a game, but it renders Ting-Lu useless for a few turns. Whirlwind works exceptionally well with other hazard setters like Ferrothorn and Mega Diancie, as it lets Ting-Lu wear down Pokemon quickly for its teammates, as well as phazing setup sweepers such as Espathra and Dragonite easily. Tera Poison grants Ting-Lu a Toxic immunity while also preventing Fairy-types like Mega Diancie and Iron Valiant from taking advatange of it. Tera Water gives Ting-Lu a solid typing defensively, letting it switch into Barraskewda and Weavile easily. Ghost is also a solid Tera type, as it lets Ting-Lu check Fighting-types like Zamazenta and Iron Valiant, as well as blocking Rapid Spin attempts from Great Tusk. Water-types such as Barraskewda, Urshifu-R, and Floatzel easily force Ting-Lu out, making Water-resistant teammates such as Ferrothorn, Slowbro, and Dragonite great partners. Due to Ting-Lu's susceptibility to Fighting-types like Mega Medicham, Great Tusk, and Zamazenta, Pokemon like Gholdengo, Tornadus-T, and Skeledirge work really well alongside it. Gholdengo in particular forms a potent defensive core with Ting-Lu, preventing its entry hazards from being Defogged. Wallbreakers such as Urshifu-R, Dragapult, and Iron Valiant all pair amazingly with Ting-Lu's hazard support. Lastly, due to Ting-Lu's susceptibility to hazard chip damage, entry hazard removers like Tornadus-T, Rotom-W, and Great Tusk are invaluable partners.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Choice Specs Iron Valiant is a threatening wallbreaker, punching holes in teams with its good offensive stats and wide special movepool. Iron Valiant can't fit all its desired options, but its versatility means opponents must scout it. Thunderbolt helps deal with Pokemon like Toxapex and Corviknight. Psyshock dents Clodsire,which usually hard counters Iron Valiant otherwise, while Shadow Ball helps against Gholdengo and Skeledirge. Trick can cripple Iron Valiant's switch-ins such as Toxapex, Clodsire, and Corviknight. Fairy is the premier Tera type to boost its Moonblast to extreme levels, with it even denting resistant foes like Gholdengo and Victini. Electric is also a good choice, as it helps against Bullet Punch from Mega Scizor and Hurricane from Tornadus-T and Zapdos, and Thunderbolt becomes an extra STAB move. Steel works in the same vein, but it doesn't have any offensive utility, although it provides Iron Valiant a Toxic immunity and more resistances. This set appreciates pivots like Landorus-T, Tapu Koko, and Slowbro to pressure the opponent's team and bring it in. In particular, Tapu Koko also boosts Iron Valiant's Speed thanks to Electric Terrain activating Quark Drive, while Slowbro provides Future Sight support, helping Iron Valiant to push through Toxapex and Clodsire. Entry hazards from Pokemon like Ting-Lu, Garchomp, and Gastrodon help wear down Iron Valiant's checks, such as Gholdengo, Clodsire, and Toxapex. They also can switch into faster Pokemon that threaten Iron Valiant, such as Tapu Koko, Choice Scarf Rotom-W, and Choice Scarf Victini. Pursuit Kingambit, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar can trap and remove Pokemon that Iron Valiant struggles to break through, like Gholdengo and Victini.

sets.name: Mixed Attacker
sets.description: Iron Valiant has the stats to be a good mixed attacker. The given EV spread allows it to OHKO Blissey with Close Combat. Psyshock helps deal with Clodsire, and Thunderbolt hits Corviknight and Toxapex. Knock Off is a good option, as it helps beat Gholdengo while usefully removing items from the likes of Skeledirge, Volcarona, and Corviknight. Fairy is the best Tera type for this set, as it lets Moonblast's damage skyrocket. Steel can make up for Iron Valiant's atrocious bulk, which is even worsened by the Naive nature, and Electric also brings some defensive use while giving Thunderbolt STAB. Both also help Iron Valiant against Tornadus-T and Mega Scizor, as it can resist Hurricane and Bullet Punch. Iron Valiant appreciates slow pivots like Landorus-T, Slowbro, and Corviknight bringing it in safely. Entry hazard control is required to ensure Iron Valiant's survivability. Therefore, Defoggers like Corviknight and Tornadus-T, Rapid Spin users like Great Tusk, and even Magic Bounce users such as Mega Diancie are good partners.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description: Calm Mind Iron Valiant is a strong wallbreaker and a potent wincon due to its offensive pressure and Speed boost from Booster Energy. It already possesses a high base Speed, meaning it outpaces every relevant Choice Scarf user besides itself. Calm Mind helps it pressure supposed checks such as Toxapex, Corviknight, and Mega Scizor, although you'll need to Terastallize Iron Valiant to beat the latter. Thunderbolt helps it hit these threats, while Psyshock allows Iron Valiant to properly beat Clodsire and the aforementioned Toxapex. Thunderbolt in combination with an Electrium Z can dent checks like Toxapex and Gholdengo once boosted. Steel is the best Tera type, as it lets Iron Valiant block poison and resist strong priority moves, such as Fake Out from Mega Lopunny and Bullet Punch from Mega Scizor. Electric is also a very strong option, as it still helps against Bullet Punch and allows Iron Valiant to bash through Skeledirge and the aforementioned Mega Scizor. Since Booster Energy only activates once, this set requires a lot of support before coming in and setting up. Therefore, it's limited to very offensive playstyles. Entry hazards from Garchomp, Ting-Lu, and Landorus-T are needed to weaken Iron Valiant's checks such as Toxapex, Clodsire, and Mega Scizor, helping it punch through them. Pokemon that share checks with Iron Valiant are also valuable teammates, like Dragon Dance Dragonite, Weavile, and Volcarona, as together they can overwhelm common checks like Corviknight and Toxapex. Iron Valiant also appreciates dual screens from Grimmsnarl or Tapu Koko. The latter brings Electric Terrain, which can be useful for Quark Drive and Thunderbolt in extended endgame scenarios. Finally, Swords Dance Kingambit and Swords Dance Garchomp can deal with its checks like Toxapex and Clodsire.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Thanks to its high Speed and capable offensive stats, Iron Valiant is a very potent Choice Scarf user, revenge killing Dragonite and Zamazenta and cleaning up weakened teams. Close Combat and Moonblast hit a large variety of Pokemon, and Knock Off cripples foes while hitting Gholdengo and Skeledirge hard. Trick cripples checks like Toxapex and Clodsire. Tera Fairy helps Iron Valiant clean through weakened teams, and Steel allows it to reliably beat Dragonite while resisting priority moves from the likes of Mega Lopunny and Mega Scizor. Entry hazards from setters like Garchomp and Ting-Lu are heavily recommended to weaken Iron Valiant's checks such as Mega Scizor, Toxapex, and Clodsire. Trappers can remove Pokemon it tends to struggle against, such as Toxapex and Gholdengo. Therefore, Heatran, Kingambit, and Weavile are good teammates. Mega Charizard Y, Heatran, and the aforementioned Kingambit can break through Iron Valiant's aforementioned checks. Finally, defensive Pokemon, such as Mega Scizor, Gholdengo, and Heatran can cover for Iron Valiant once it gets forced out after revenge killing.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: A complementary typing and a great Attack stat, especially when considering the 1.2x boost from its Wellspring Mask, give Ogerpon-W a niche as a powerful wallbreaker. Water- and Grass-type attacks hit most Pokemon for at least neutral damage, and after a Swords Dance boost, anything that doesn't resist its STAB combination is KOed. Even checks such as Baxcalibur and Tera Grass Heatran struggle to take a Swords Dance-bolstered Ivy Cudgel, and some of the stoutest walls, such as Toxapex, take heavy damage from a boosted Power Whip. Ivy Cudgel is its strongest Water-type STAB option and hits most Pokemon for neutral damage. Power Whip punishes common Water-resistant Pokemon such as Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Alomomola and is preferred to Wood Hammer despite the potential inaccuracy to avoid recoil. Horn Leech can also be used in order to supplement Ogerpon-W's longevity and let it come in more often. Trailblaze is another niche option, usually seen on Aurora Veil or dual screens hyper offense teams, boosting Ogerpon-W's Speed and allowing it to sweep. Play Rough notably hits Dragon-types that otherwise could resist Ogerpon-W's STAB combination such as Baxcalibur and Dragonite. Superpower is another great option, notably KOing Ferrothorn after a Swords Dance boost. Due to its great wallbreaking capability, setup sweepers such as Volcarona and Booster Energy Iron Valiant appreciate defensive cores being heavily weakened, allowing them to sweep. Water Absorb is a particularly useful ability prior to Terastallizing, as Ogerpon-W can find opportunities to set up on Pokemon such as Mega Swampert and Manaphy, as well as block Alomomola's Flip Turn. Ogerpon-W also appreciates entry hazards from Hisuian Samurott and Landorus-T, as the chip helps it pressure defensive cores even further. Despite all this, bulky Grass-types such as Ferrothorn, Amoonguss, and Kartana can check Ogerpon-W, so Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Mega Medicham, and Zapdos are beneficial as teammates. Ogerpon-W is also threatened by faster attackers like Iron Valiant and Mega Lopunny, so defensive pivots such as Landorus-T, Galarian Slowking, and Mega Scizor are also extremely useful. Despite being locked to Tera Water, this is actually very beneficial to Ogerpon-W, taking away its weaknesses to Flying- and Poison-type attacks and letting it stay in on threats such as Tornadus-T and Sneasler. In addition, Tera Water boosts its Ivy Cudgel to stupendous amounts, 2HKOing Ferrothorn after Stealth Rock and minimal chip at +2. The 1.5x Special Defense boost granted upon Terastallizing can also help mitigate attempts to revenge kill Ogerpon-W by foes like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo.
